Conventions

  • •

    By Lie group, we mean either real or complex.

  • •

    A closed Lie subgroup of a Lie group is a submanifold that is also a subgroup (see Theorem 3).

  • •

    A Lie subgroup is a subgroup that is also an immersed submanifold.

Chapter 1 Lie groups: basic definitions

We will have two notions of subgroups of Lie groups:

Definition 1.0.1.

Let G𝐺G be a complex or real Lie group and H𝐻H be a subgroup of G𝐺G.

  1. (i)

    H𝐻H is a Lie subgroup if it is an immersed submanifold of G𝐺G with the multiplication and inverse maps being smooth (or analytic).

  2. (ii)

    H𝐻H is a closed Lie subgroup if it is an embedded submanifold of G𝐺G.

Example 1.0.1.

Any of the classical Lie groups are closed Lie subgroups of GL⁡(n,𝕂)GL𝑛𝕂\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(n,\mathbb{K}). For a Lie subgroup that is not closed, consider the irrational winding on the torus, that is G=𝕋2=ℝ2/ℤ2𝐺superscript𝕋2superscriptℝ2superscriptℤ2G=\mathbb{T}^{2}=\mathbb{R}^{2}/\mathbb{Z}^{2}, and H=f​(ℝ)𝐻𝑓ℝH=f(\mathbb{R}) with f​(t,s)=(tmodℤ,α​smodℤ)𝑓𝑡𝑠modulo𝑡ℤmodulo𝛼𝑠ℤf(t,s)=(t\mod\mathbb{Z},\alpha s\mod\mathbb{Z}), where α∈ℝ\ℚ𝛼\ℝℚ\alpha\in\mathbb{R}\backslash\mathbb{Q}.

1.1 Lie subgroups and quotients

The following theorem allows us to reduce the study of Lie groups to the study of finite groups and connected Lie groups, since G0subscript𝐺0G_{0} is a normal subgroup of G𝐺G and G/G0𝐺subscript𝐺0G/G_{0} is a discrete group. where G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is the identity component of G𝐺G.

Theorem 1 (Theorem 2.6, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a real or complex Lie group and G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} its identity component. Then G0superscript𝐺0G^{0} is a normal subgroup of G𝐺G and a Lie group itself, while G/G0𝐺superscript𝐺0G/G^{0} is a discrete group.

In fact, we can reduce the case of connected Lie groups to simply connected Lie groups:

Theorem 2 (Theorem 2.7, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a connected Lie group. Then its universal cover G~~𝐺\tilde{G} has a canonical structure of a Lie group such that the covering map p:G~→G:𝑝→~𝐺𝐺p:\tilde{G}\to G is a homomorphism of Lie groups whose kernel is isomorphic to the fundamental group of G𝐺G. Moreover, in this case, ker⁡pkernel𝑝\ker p is a discrete central subgroup in G~~𝐺\tilde{G}.

Proof.

The lifting property of the universal cover implies that G~~𝐺\tilde{G} is a Lie group. The kernel is discrete, being the fiber of a covering map. The fact that it is central follows from the more general fact that every discrete normal subgroup of a connected Lie group is central. To show the latter, one considers the map G→N,g→g​n​g−1formulae-sequence→𝐺𝑁→𝑔𝑔𝑛superscript𝑔1G\to N,g\to gng^{-1} where N𝑁N is the normal subgroup and n∈N𝑛𝑁n\in N is some fixed element. Then the inverse image of any element n′∈Nsuperscript𝑛′𝑁n^{\prime}\in N is closed an open in G𝐺G, so it is all of G𝐺G in the case where n′=nsuperscript𝑛′𝑛n^{\prime}=n and empty otherwise. ∎

Example 1.1.1.

In the case where G=𝕋2𝐺superscript𝕋2G=\mathbb{T}^{2} is the torus, the covering map p:ℝ2→𝕋2:𝑝→superscriptℝ2superscript𝕋2p:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{T}^{2} is given by p​(t,s)=e2​π​i​t,2​π​i​s𝑝𝑡𝑠superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑡2𝜋𝑖𝑠p(t,s)=e^{2\pi it,2\pi is}, and ker⁡p=ℕ2≃π1​(𝕋2)kernel𝑝superscriptℕ2similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜋1superscript𝕋2\ker p=\mathbb{N}^{2}\simeq\pi_{1}(\mathbb{T}^{2}).

We have the following connection between subgroups and Lie subgroups (i.e. subgroups that are also submanifolds):

Theorem 3 (Theorem 2.8, [Kir08]).
  1. (i)

    Any Lie subgroup of a Lie group is closed in the topology of the ambient group.

  2. (ii)

    Any closed subgroup of a Lie group is a real Lie subgroup.

Proof.

For the first part of the theorem, we note that H¯¯𝐻\overline{H} is a subgroup of G𝐺G as well. We claim that H𝐻H (and thus H​x𝐻𝑥Hx for every x∈H¯𝑥¯𝐻x\in\overline{H} ) is open and dense in H¯¯𝐻\overline{H}. To see this, note that e∈H¯𝑒¯𝐻e\in\overline{H} implies that for every neighborhood U⊆G𝑈𝐺U\subseteq G of e𝑒e in G𝐺G, U∩H𝑈𝐻U\cap H is nonempty. In particular there exists some open set U𝑈U in G𝐺G containing r𝑟r such that U∩H≠∅𝑈𝐻U\cap H\neq\emptyset. Then U∩H𝑈𝐻U\cap H will be a neighborhood of e𝑒e in H¯¯𝐻\overline{H} and H𝐻H is open because it can be written as the union of all subsets of the form h​(U∩H)ℎ𝑈𝐻h(U\cap H) for h∈Hℎ𝐻h\in H.

To conclude, note that for x,y∈H¯𝑥𝑦¯𝐻x,y\in\overline{H}, H​x∩H​y𝐻𝑥𝐻𝑦Hx\cap Hy is dense in H¯¯𝐻\overline{H}, so it is nonempty. This implies that H​x=H​y=H𝐻𝑥𝐻𝑦𝐻Hx=Hy=H and H𝐻H thus H=H¯𝐻¯𝐻H=\overline{H}. ∎

1.2 Homogeneous spaces

We begin by describing coset spaces of Lie groups.

Theorem 4 (Theorem 2.11, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group of dimension n𝑛n, H≤G𝐻𝐺H\leq G a closed Lie subgroup of dimension k𝑘k.

  1. (i)

    The coset space G/H𝐺𝐻G/H has a natural structure of a manifold of dimension n−k𝑛𝑘n-k such that the canonical map p:G→G/H:𝑝→𝐺𝐺𝐻p:G\to G/H is a fiber bundle, with fiber diffeomorphic to H𝐻H. The tangent space at the identity is isomorphic to the quotient space TH​G/H≃Te​G/Te​Hsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝑇𝐻𝐺𝐻subscript𝑇𝑒𝐺subscript𝑇𝑒𝐻T_{H}G/H\simeq T_{e}G/T_{e}H.

  2. (ii)

    If H is a normal closed Lie subgroup then G/H𝐺𝐻G/H has a canonical Lie group structure.

The following is the analog of the homomorphism theorem for Lie groups:

Theorem 5 (Theorem 2.5, [Kir08]).

Let f:G1→G2:𝑓→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2f:G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Lie group morphism.

  1. (i)

    H=ker⁡f𝐻kernel𝑓H=\ker f is a normal closed Lie subgroup of G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and f𝑓f induces an injective homomorphism G1/H→G2→subscript𝐺1𝐻subscript𝐺2G_{1}/H\to G_{2} that is an immersion

  2. (ii)

    If moreover ℑ⁡f𝑓\Im f is an embedded submanifold, then it is a closed Lie subgroup of G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} and f𝑓f induces an isomorphism G1/H→ℑ⁡f→subscript𝐺1𝐻𝑓G_{1}/H\to\Im f.

Theorem 6 (Theorem 2.20, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group acting on a manifold M𝑀M, and m∈M𝑚𝑀m\in M.

  1. (i)

    The stabilizer Gmsubscript𝐺𝑚G_{m} is a closed Lie subgroup of G𝐺G, with Lie algebra

    𝔥={x∈𝔤∣ρ∗​(x)​(m)=0}.𝔥conditional-set𝑥𝔤subscript𝜌𝑥𝑚0\mathfrak{h}=\{x\in\mathfrak{g}\mid\rho_{*}(x)(m)=0\}.

    where ρ:G→Diff​(M):𝜌→𝐺Diff𝑀\rho:G\to\mathrm{Diff}(M) is the action of G𝐺G on M𝑀M.

  2. (ii)

    The orbit map g↦g⋅mmaps-to𝑔⋅𝑔𝑚g\mapsto g\cdot m induces an injective immersion G/Gm↪𝒪m↪𝐺subscript𝐺𝑚subscript𝒪𝑚G/G_{m}\hookrightarrow\mathcal{O}_{m} whose image coincides with 𝒪msubscript𝒪𝑚\mathcal{O}_{m}.

  3. (iii)

    The orbit 𝒪msubscript𝒪𝑚\mathcal{O}_{m} is an immersed submanifold with tangent space Tm​𝒪m=𝔤/𝔥subscript𝑇𝑚subscript𝒪𝑚𝔤𝔥T_{m}\mathcal{O}_{m}=\mathfrak{g}/\mathfrak{h}.

Proof.

See [Kir08, Theorem 2.20, Theorem 3.29]. ∎

The case of one orbit gives rise to G𝐺G-homogeneous spaces:

Theorem 7 (Theorem 2.22 [Kir08]).

Let M𝑀M be a G𝐺G-homogeneous space and m∈M𝑚𝑀m\in M. Then the orbit map G→M→𝐺𝑀G\to M is a fiber bundle over M𝑀M with fiber Gmsubscript𝐺𝑚G_{m}.

The following proposition gives us a way to check whether a Lie group morphism is a covering map:

Proposition 1.2.1 (Lie morphism covering map criterion).

Let f:G1→G2:𝑓→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2f:G_{1}\to G_{2} be a Lie group morphism such that f∗:𝔤1→𝔤2:subscript𝑓→subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2f_{*}:\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2} is an isomorphism. Then f𝑓f is a covering map and ker⁡fkernel𝑓\ker f is a discrete central group.

Proof.

The inverse mapping theorem tells us that there exist neighborhoods U1,U2subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2U_{1},U_{2} of the identities of G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2} respectively such that f:U1→U2:𝑓→subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2f:U_{1}\to U_{2} is a diffeomorphism. In particular, f𝑓f is surjective since its image contains U2subscript𝑈2U_{2} which generates G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}, being a neighborhood of the identity. Moreover, for every g∈G1𝑔subscript𝐺1g\in G_{1} and z1,z2∈ker⁡fsubscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2kernel𝑓z_{1},z_{2}\in\ker f:

g​U1​z1∩g​U2​z2={e1}​ unless ​z1=z2.𝑔subscript𝑈1subscript𝑧1𝑔subscript𝑈2subscript𝑧2subscript𝑒1 unless subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2gU_{1}z_{1}\cap gU_{2}z_{2}=\{e_{1}\}\text{ unless }z_{1}=z_{2}.

Indeed, if g​u​z1=g​v​z2𝑔𝑢subscript𝑧1𝑔𝑣subscript𝑧2guz_{1}=gvz_{2} for some u,v∈U𝑢𝑣𝑈u,v\in U, then u=v​z2​z1−1𝑢𝑣subscript𝑧2superscriptsubscript𝑧11u=vz_{2}z_{1}^{-1}, so f​(u)=f​(v)𝑓𝑢𝑓𝑣f(u)=f(v). But f𝑓f being injective on U1subscript𝑈1U_{1}, this implies u=v𝑢𝑣u=v and z1=z2subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2z_{1}=z_{2}.

Thus f​(g)​U1𝑓𝑔subscript𝑈1f(g)U_{1} is an evenly covered neighborhood for every f​(g)∈G2𝑓𝑔subscript𝐺2f(g)\in G_{2}.

f−1​(f​(g)​U2)=g​U1​ker⁡f=⨆z∈ker⁡fg​U1​z.superscript𝑓1𝑓𝑔subscript𝑈2𝑔subscript𝑈1kernel𝑓subscriptsquare-union𝑧kernel𝑓𝑔subscript𝑈1𝑧f^{-1}(f(g)U_{2})=gU_{1}\ker f=\bigsqcup_{z\in\ker f}gU_{1}z.

To see that ker⁡fkernel𝑓\ker f is discrete, note that the injectivity of f𝑓f implies U1∩ker⁡f={e1}subscript𝑈1kernel𝑓subscript𝑒1U_{1}\cap\ker f=\{e_{1}\}. Being a discrete normal subgroup, it must also be central. ∎

1.3 Classical Lie groups

We also define the gorup of unitary quaternionic transformations by

The following theorem tells us that the logarithmic map behaves well when restricted to a neighborhood of the identity in each classical group.

Chapter 2 Lie groups and Lie algebras

2.1 Exponential map

Definition 2.1.1 (Proposition 3.1, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group and x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}. The one-parameter subgroup γx:𝕂→G:subscript𝛾𝑥→𝕂𝐺\gamma_{x}:\mathbb{K}\to G is the unique Lie group morphism such that γx′​(0)=xsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑥′0𝑥\gamma_{x}^{\prime}(0)=x. We define the exponential map of G𝐺G as

exp⁡(x)=γx​(1)𝑥subscript𝛾𝑥1\exp(x)=\gamma_{x}(1)
Remark 2.1.1.

By looking at the proof of the statements in the above definition, one can see that for x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}, the curve

exp⁡(t​x)=γx​(t)=γt​x​(1).𝑡𝑥subscript𝛾𝑥𝑡subscript𝛾𝑡𝑥1\exp(tx)=\gamma_{x}(t)=\gamma_{tx}(1).

integral curve of the left-invariant vector field X∈𝒳​(G)𝑋𝒳𝐺X\in\mathcal{X}(G) that satisfies

Xe=x.subscript𝑋𝑒𝑥X_{e}=x.

The following are some properties of the exponential map:

Theorem 8 (Theorems 3.7 and 3.36, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group.

  1. (i)

    de​exp=id𝔤subscript𝑑𝑒subscriptid𝔤d_{e}\exp=\operatorname{id}_{\mathfrak{g}}

  2. (ii)

    The exponential map is a local diffeomorphism at 00.

  3. (iii)

    For any Lie group morphism ϕ:G1→G2:italic-ϕ→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2\phi:G_{1}\to G_{2}, we have de​ϕ​(e​x​p​(x))=exp⁡de​(ϕ​(x))subscript𝑑𝑒italic-ϕ𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑥subscript𝑑𝑒italic-ϕ𝑥d_{e}\phi(exp(x))=\exp d_{e}(\phi(x)) for all x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}.

  4. (iv)

    For any g∈G,x∈𝔤formulae-sequence𝑔𝐺𝑥𝔤g\in G,x\in\mathfrak{g}

    If ​[x,y]=0​ then ​ex​ey=ey​ex=ex+y.If 𝑥𝑦0 then superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑥𝑦\text{If }[x,y]=0\text{ then }e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x}=e^{x+y}.
Remark 2.1.2.

The exponential map is not surjective in general. It is however for compact Lie groups.

Lemma 2.1.1.

The exponential map of a connected Lie group G𝐺G sends generators of ℊℊ\mathcal{g} to generators of G𝐺G. That is, if {x1,…,xn}subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\} is a basis of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}, then {exp⁡(t​xi):t∈ℝ,i∈⟦1,n⟧}conditional-set𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖formulae-sequence𝑡ℝ𝑖1𝑛\left\{\exp(tx_{i}):t\in\mathbb{R},i\in\llbracket 1,n\rrbracket\right\} is a basis of G𝐺G.

Proof.

Consider the map f:ℝn→𝔾:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛𝔾f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{G} given by

f​(t1,…,tn)=exp⁡(t1​x1)​⋯​exp⁡(tn​xn).𝑓subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑡1subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑥𝑛f(t_{1},\ldots,t_{n})=\exp(t_{1}x_{1})\cdots\exp(t_{n}x_{n}).

Then d0​f=Insubscript𝑑0𝑓subscript𝐼𝑛d_{0}f=I_{n} in the basis with respect to the standard basis for ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} and {x1,…,xn}subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\} for 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. In particular it is surjective and by the constant rank theorem, f​(ℝn)𝑓superscriptℝ𝑛f(\mathbb{R}^{n}) contatins a neighborhood of the identity of G𝐺G. ∎

Example 2.1.1.

Let G=S​O​(3,ℝ)𝐺𝑆𝑂3ℝG=SO(3,\mathbb{R}). Then 𝔰​𝔬​(3,ℝ)𝔰𝔬3ℝ\mathfrak{so}(3,\mathbb{R}) consists of skew-symmetric mattrices, with basis:

J1=(00000−1010),J2=(001000−100),J3=(0−10100000).formulae-sequencesubscript𝐽1matrix000001010formulae-sequencesubscript𝐽2matrix001000100subscript𝐽3matrix010100000\displaystyle J_{1}=\begin{pmatrix}0&0&0\\ 0&0&-1\\ 0&1&0\end{pmatrix},\quad J_{2}=\begin{pmatrix}0&0&1\\ 0&0&0\\ -1&0&0\end{pmatrix},\quad J_{3}=\begin{pmatrix}0&-1&0\\ 1&0&0\\ 0&0&0\end{pmatrix}.

The exponential matrix is given by

et​J1=(1000cos⁡(t)−sin⁡(t)0sin⁡(t)cos⁡(t)),superscript𝑒𝑡subscript𝐽1matrix1000𝑡𝑡0𝑡𝑡e^{tJ_{1}}=\begin{pmatrix}1&0&0\\ 0&\cos(t)&-\sin(t)\\ 0&\sin(t)&\cos(t)\end{pmatrix},

i.e. rotation around x-axis by angle t; similarly, Jy,Jzsubscript𝐽𝑦subscript𝐽𝑧J_{y},J_{z} generate rotations around y,z𝑦𝑧y,z axes. Elements of the form e​x​p​(t​J​x),e​x​p​(t​Jy),e​x​p​(t​Jz)𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑡𝐽𝑥𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑡subscript𝐽𝑦𝑒𝑥𝑝𝑡subscript𝐽𝑧exp(tJx),exp(tJ_{y}),exp(tJ_{z}) generate a neighborhood of identity in SO⁡(3,ℝ)SO3ℝ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(3,\mathbb{R}). Since S​O​(3,ℝ)𝑆𝑂3ℝSO(3,\mathbb{R}) is connected, these elements generate the whole group. For this reason, it is common to refer to Jx,Jy,Jzsubscript𝐽𝑥subscript𝐽𝑦subscript𝐽𝑧J_{x},J_{y},J_{z} as “infinitesimal generators” of S​O​(3,ℝ)𝑆𝑂3ℝSO(3,\mathbb{R}). Thus, in a certain sense S​O​(3,ℝ)𝑆𝑂3ℝSO(3,\mathbb{R}) is generated by three elements.

Remark 2.1.3.

To motivate the term “infinitesimal generators”, one can think of them as directions in which one can move from the identity (using the exponential map) in order to generate the whole group.

2.2 The commutator

In literature, one has at least three (and four in the case of vector fields) ways to define the commutator of some Lie group, Namely

  1. (i)

    Using left-invariant vector fields (see [Lee18]).

  2. (ii)

    As the lowest order term in the logarithm of the multiplication of exponentials (see Lemma 2.2.1).

  3. (iii)

    As the differential of the adjoint representation.

  4. (iv)

    In the case of vector fields, as the differentiation of the second vector field along the first.

For completeness, we recall that in [Lee18], the commutator of a Lie group is defined as

[x,y]=[X,Y]e​ for ​x,y∈𝔤formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦subscript𝑋𝑌𝑒 for 𝑥𝑦𝔤[x,y]=[X,Y]_{e}\text{ for }x,y\in\mathfrak{g}

where X,Y𝑋𝑌X,Y are the left-invariant vector fields for which Xe=x,Ye=yformulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑒𝑥subscript𝑌𝑒𝑦X_{e}=x,Y_{e}=y, and the bracket of two vector fields is defined as [X,Y]=X​Y−Y​X𝑋𝑌𝑋𝑌𝑌𝑋[X,Y]=XY-YX.

In [Kir08], the commutator is defined as the lowest order term in the logarithm of the multiplication of exponentials (see Lemma 2.2.1). We say that a map Q:𝔤→𝔤:𝑄→𝔤𝔤Q:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{g} is of order k𝑘k if Q​(t​x)=tk​Q​(X)𝑄𝑡𝑥superscript𝑡𝑘𝑄𝑋Q(tx)=t^{k}Q(X) for t∈ℝ,x∈𝔤formulae-sequence𝑡ℝ𝑥𝔤t\in\mathbb{R},x\in\mathfrak{g}.

Lemma 2.2.1 (Lemma 3.11, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group. Then there exists a neighborhood of 0∈𝔤0𝔤0\in\mathfrak{g} and smooth (or analytic in the complex case) functions [⋅,⋅],μ:𝔤×𝔤→𝔤:⋅⋅𝜇→𝔤𝔤𝔤[\cdot,\cdot],\mu:\mathfrak{g}\times\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{g} such that in that neighborhood:

with [⋅,⋅]⋅⋅[\cdot,\cdot] being a bilinear skew-symmetric form and the dots denoting terms of order higher than 333.

The commutator has the following properties:

Let G,H𝐺𝐻G,H be Lie groups and ϕ:G→H:italic-ϕ→𝐺𝐻\phi:G\to H a Lie group morphism. Then for x,y∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝔤x,y\in\mathfrak{g} we have

For instance when G𝐺G is commutative, the commutator is zero (and the exponential map is a homomorphism).

Example 2.2.1.
  1. (i)

    For 𝔤=𝔤​𝔩​(d,𝕂)𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑑𝕂\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{gl}(d,\mathbb{K}), the commutator is given by

    [x,y]=x​y−y​x.𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦𝑦𝑥[x,y]=xy-yx.
  2. (ii)

    For a general associative algebra A𝐴A, the commutator over 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, is given by the same formula.

  3. (iii)

    Any vector space can be made into a commutative Lie algebra by defining the commutator to be zero.

Theorem 9 (Jacobi identity).

Let G𝐺G be a real or complex Lie group and x,y,z∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝑧𝔤x,y,z\in\mathfrak{g}. Then

[x,[y,z]]+[y,[z,x]]+[z,[x,y]]=0.𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑦𝑧𝑥𝑧𝑥𝑦0[x,[y,z]]+[y,[z,x]]+[z,[x,y]]=0.
Proof.

See [Kir08, Theorem 3.16]. ∎

Proposition 2.2.2.

Differentiation at the identity induces a map

hom⁡(G1,G2)→hom⁡(𝔤1,𝔤2)→homsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2homsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\hom(G_{1},G_{2})\to\hom(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2})

which is injective when G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} is connected.

2.3 Subalgebras, ideals and center

Definition 2.3.1.

A subalgebra of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a subspace 𝔥⊆𝔤𝔥𝔤\mathfrak{h}\subseteq\mathfrak{g} that is closed under the Lie bracket: [x,y]∈𝔥𝑥𝑦𝔥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all x,y∈𝔥𝑥𝑦𝔥x,y\in\mathfrak{h}. An ideal is a subalgebra 𝔥𝔥\mathfrak{h} such that [x,y]∈𝔥𝑥𝑦𝔥[x,y]\in\mathfrak{h} for all x∈𝔥,y∈𝔤formulae-sequence𝑥𝔥𝑦𝔤x\in\mathfrak{h},y\in\mathfrak{g}.

Given some ideals, we can perform operations on them to get new ideals:

Proposition 2.3.1 (Proposition 3.19, [Kir08]).

Let I1,I2subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2I_{1},I_{2} be ideals of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then I1+I2,I1∩I2,[I1,I2]subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2I_{1}+I_{2},I_{1}\cap I_{2},[I_{1},I_{2}] are ideals as well.

It is easy to see a quotient of a Lie algebra by an ideal carries a canonical structure of a Lie algebra. We moreover have the following lemma, reminiscent of the homomorphism theorem for groups:

Lemma 2.3.1.

Let f:𝔤1→𝔤2:𝑓→subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2f:\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2} be a Lie algebra morphism. Then ker⁡fkernel𝑓\ker f is an ideal of 𝔤1,Im⁡fsubscript𝔤1Im𝑓\mathfrak{g}_{1},\operatorname{{\mathrm{Im}}}f is a subalgebra of 𝔤2subscript𝔤2\mathfrak{g}_{2} and f𝑓f gives rise to an isomorphism of Lie algebras: 𝔤1/ker⁡f≃Im⁡fsimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝔤1kernel𝑓Im𝑓\mathfrak{g}_{1}/\ker f\simeq\operatorname{{\mathrm{Im}}}f.

The next theorem tells us that Lie subgroups correspond to subalgebras, and normal closed Lie subgroups correspond to ideals. In the case of the latter, a converse statement gives us a way to check if a subgroup is normal by checking whether the corresponding subalgebra is an ideal. In this way we obtain a link between an algebraic condition (being a normal subgroup) and a linear one (being an ideal).

Theorem 10 (Theorem 3.22, [Kir08]).

Let G𝐺G be a real or complex Lie group with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then

  1. (i)

    If H𝐻H is a Lie subgroup (not necessarily closed) of G𝐺G, then 𝔥𝔥\mathfrak{h} is a subalgebra of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

  2. (ii)

    If H𝐻H is a normal closed Lie subgroup of G𝐺G, then 𝔥𝔥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

  3. (iii)

    If H𝐻H is a closed Lie subgroup of G𝐺G, both G𝐺G and H𝐻H are connected, then 𝔥𝔥\mathfrak{h} is an ideal of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} if and only if H𝐻H is a normal subgroup of G𝐺G.

One of the first ways to study a Lie algebra is by analyzing how close it is to a commutative Lie algebra. There are numerous ways to do this, some of which will be elaborated below.

  1. (i)

    By looking at the center 𝔷​(𝔤)=ker⁡ad𝔷𝔤kernelad\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g})=\ker\operatorname{ad} of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. The bigger the center, the more commutative the Lie algebra.

  2. (ii)

    By looking at the commutator [𝔤,𝔤]𝔤𝔤[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}]. The smaller the commutator, the more commutative the Lie algebra.

  3. (iii)

    By looking at the degree of solvability of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. The smaller the degree of solvability, the more commutative the Lie algebra, since derived series are merely succesive extensions of commutative subalgebras.

To support this, take for instance the commutant. It is the smallest ideal of the Lie algebra, such that the quotient is abelian.

Lemma 2.3.2.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra. Then for every ideal I𝐼I of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} such that the quotient 𝔤/I𝔤𝐼\mathfrak{g}/I is abelian, I⊇[𝔤,𝔤]𝔤𝔤𝐼I\supseteq[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}].

Going on to solvable algebras, we give the following definition.

Definition 2.3.2.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra. We define the derived series of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} as the decreasing sequence of ideals

Di​𝔤=[Di​𝔤,Di​𝔤],superscript𝐷𝑖𝔤superscript𝐷𝑖𝔤superscript𝐷𝑖𝔤D^{i}\mathfrak{g}=[D^{i}\mathfrak{g},D^{i}\mathfrak{g}],

starting with D0​𝔤=𝔤superscript𝐷0𝔤𝔤D^{0}\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{g}. The Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is said to be solvable if one of the following equivalent conditions holds:

  1. (i)

    The derived series terminates, i.e. there exists n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} such that Dn​𝔤=0superscript𝐷𝑛𝔤0D^{n}\mathfrak{g}=0.

  2. (ii)

    There exists a chain of subalgebras 𝔞0=𝔤⊇𝔞1⊇⋯⊇𝔞k=0superscript𝔞0𝔤superset-of-or-equalssuperscript𝔞1superset-of-or-equals⋯superset-of-or-equalssuperscript𝔞𝑘0\mathfrak{a}^{0}=\mathfrak{g}\supseteq\mathfrak{a}^{1}\supseteq\cdots\supseteq\mathfrak{a}^{k}=0 such that 𝔞isuperscript𝔞𝑖\mathfrak{a}^{i} is an ideal in 𝔞isuperscript𝔞𝑖\mathfrak{a}^{i} and the quotient 𝔞i/𝔞i+1superscript𝔞𝑖superscript𝔞𝑖1\mathfrak{a}^{i}/\mathfrak{a}^{i+1} is abelian.

  3. (iii)

    For large enough n𝑛n, every commutator of the form [x1,[x2,…​[xn−1,xn]​…]]subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛1subscript𝑥𝑛…[x_{1},[x_{2},\ldots[x_{n-1},x_{n}]\ldots]] (2nsuperscript2𝑛2^{n} terms arranged in a binary tree of length n𝑛n) is zero (see Figure 2.2).

Similar to the solvable algebras, we also have the notion of nilpotent algebras.

Definition 2.3.3.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra. We define the lower central series of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} as the decreasing sequence of ideals, begining with D0​𝔤=𝔤subscript𝐷0𝔤𝔤D_{0}\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{g} and

Di+1​𝔤=[𝔤,Di​𝔤].subscript𝐷𝑖1𝔤𝔤subscript𝐷𝑖𝔤D_{i+1}\mathfrak{g}=[\mathfrak{g},D_{i}\mathfrak{g}].

The algebra is called nilpotent if one of the following conditions holds:

  1. (i)

    The lower central series terminates, i.e. there exists n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} such that Dn​𝔤=0subscript𝐷𝑛𝔤0D_{n}\mathfrak{g}=0.

  2. (ii)

    There exists a chain of ideals 𝔞0=𝔤⊇𝔞1⊇⋯⊇𝔞k=0subscript𝔞0𝔤superset-of-or-equalssubscript𝔞1superset-of-or-equals⋯superset-of-or-equalssubscript𝔞𝑘0\mathfrak{a}_{0}=\mathfrak{g}\supseteq\mathfrak{a}_{1}\supseteq\cdots\supseteq\mathfrak{a}_{k}=0 such that [𝔤,𝔞i]⊆𝔞i+1𝔤subscript𝔞𝑖subscript𝔞𝑖1[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{a}_{i}]\subseteq\mathfrak{a}_{i+1}.

  3. (iii)

    For large enough n𝑛n, every commutator of the form [x1,[x2,…​[xn−1,xn]​…]]subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛1subscript𝑥𝑛…[x_{1},[x_{2},\ldots[x_{n-1},x_{n}]\ldots]] (n𝑛n terms) is zero (see Figure 2.2).

An important example is 𝔤​𝔩​(n,𝕂)𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂\mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb{K}). Before we describe it, we make some preliminary remarks that will facilitate the computations. Example 2.3.1.

The commutator of 𝔤​𝔩​(n,𝕂)𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂\mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb{K}) is given by

[𝔤​𝔩⁡(n,𝕂),𝔤​𝔩⁡(n,𝕂)]=𝔰​𝔩⁡(n,𝕂).𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂𝔰𝔩𝑛𝕂[\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(n,\mathbb{K}),\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(n,\mathbb{K})]=\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(n,\mathbb{K}).

Let now 𝔟⊆𝔤​𝔩⁡(n,𝕂)𝔟𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(n,\mathbb{K}) be the subalgebra of upper triangular matrices and 𝔫𝔫\mathfrak{n} be the subalgebra of strictly upper triangular matrices. Then 𝔟𝔟\mathfrak{b} is solvable and 𝔫𝔫\mathfrak{n} is nilpotent.

Noting that 𝔟=𝔟​(ℱ0),𝔫=𝔫​(ℱ0)formulae-sequence𝔟𝔟subscriptℱ0𝔫𝔫subscriptℱ0\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{b}(\mathcal{F}_{0}),\mathfrak{n}=\mathfrak{n}(\mathcal{F}_{0}) for ℱ0subscriptℱ0\mathcal{F}_{0} being the standard flag in 𝕂nsuperscript𝕂𝑛\mathbb{K}^{n}, we have seen above that 𝔫𝔫\mathfrak{n} is nilpotent.

To see that 𝔟𝔟\mathfrak{b} is solvable, note that D1​𝔟=[𝔟,𝔟]⊆𝔫=𝔞isuperscript𝐷1𝔟𝔟𝔟𝔫subscript𝔞𝑖D^{1}\mathfrak{b}=[\mathfrak{b},\mathfrak{b}]\subseteq\mathfrak{n}=\mathfrak{a}_{i} since the diagonal entries of x​y𝑥𝑦xy and y​x𝑦𝑥yx coincide. Inductively, this implies that Di+1​𝔟⊆𝔞2isuperscript𝐷𝑖1𝔟subscript𝔞superscript2𝑖D^{i+1}\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\mathfrak{a}_{2^{i}}.

Note finally that 𝔟𝔟\mathfrak{b} is not nilpotent because Di​𝔟=𝔫subscript𝐷𝑖𝔟𝔫D_{i}\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{n}. Indeed, we have seen that D1​𝔟=[𝔟,𝔟]⊆𝔫subscript𝐷1𝔟𝔟𝔟𝔫D_{1}\mathfrak{b}=[\mathfrak{b},\mathfrak{b}]\subseteq\mathfrak{n}. On the other hand, the relation

Ei​j​Ek​l=δj​k​Ei​lsubscript𝐸𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑘𝑙subscript𝛿𝑗𝑘subscript𝐸𝑖𝑙E_{ij}E_{kl}=\delta_{jk}E_{il}

tells us that Ei​j=[Ei​i,Ei​j]∈D2​𝔟subscript𝐸𝑖𝑗subscript𝐸𝑖𝑖subscript𝐸𝑖𝑗subscript𝐷2𝔟E_{ij}=[E_{ii},E_{ij}]\in D_{2}\mathfrak{b}, so D2​𝔟=D1​𝔟=𝔫subscript𝐷2𝔟subscript𝐷1𝔟𝔫D_{2}\mathfrak{b}=D_{1}\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{n}, so it follows by induction.

Finally, we have the following properties for solvable and nilpotent algebras.

Proposition 2.3.2.
  1. (i)

    A real Lie algebra is solvable (resp. nilpotent) if and only if its complexification is.

  2. (ii)

    If 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable (resp. nilpotent), then every subalgebra and quotient of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable (and resp. nilpotent).

  3. (iii)

    If 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is nilpotent, it is solvable.

  4. (iv)

    If I⊆𝔤𝐼𝔤I\subseteq\mathfrak{g} is an ideal such that both 𝔤,𝔤/I𝔤𝔤𝐼\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}/I are solvable, then 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable.

Proof.

For certain points, it is useful to note that if I⊆𝔤𝐼𝔤I\subseteq\mathfrak{g} is an ideal, then Di​(g/I)=(Di​𝔤)+Isuperscript𝐷𝑖𝑔𝐼superscript𝐷𝑖𝔤𝐼D^{i}\mathfrak{(}g/I)=(D^{i}\mathfrak{g})+I. ∎

2.4 Lie algebra of vector fields

For a manifold M𝑀M, the space Vect​(M)Vect𝑀\mathrm{Vect}(M) can be made into a Lie algebra by directly defining the bracket of two vector fields and showing that it is skew-symmetric and bilinear. However, one can think of Diff​(M)Diff𝑀\mathrm{Diff}(M) as similar to a Lie group (but not quite, since it is infinite-dimensional), whose Lie algebra is Vect​(M)Vect𝑀\mathrm{Vect}(M).

Definition 2.4.1.

Let M𝑀M be a smooth manifold and G𝐺G be a Lie group.

  1. (i)

    A smooth map ρ:G→Diff​(M):𝜌→𝐺Diff𝑀\rho:G\to\mathrm{Diff}(M) is a map that arises from a smooth action of G𝐺G on M𝑀M.

  2. (ii)

    The Lie algebra of Diff​(M)Diff𝑀\mathrm{Diff}(M) is the space of vector fields Vect​(M)Vect𝑀\mathrm{Vect}(M).

  3. (iii)

    The exponential map of Diff​(M)Diff𝑀\mathrm{Diff}(M) is the flow (whenever well-defined) of a vector field: (eX)m=ΦX1​(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑋𝑚subscriptsuperscriptΦ1𝑋𝑚\left(e^{X}\right)_{m}=\Phi^{1}_{X}(m).

  4. (iv)

    The differential of ρ:G→Diff​(M):𝜌→𝐺Diff𝑀\rho:G\to\mathrm{Diff}(M) is the map ρ∗:𝔤→Vect​(M):subscript𝜌→𝔤Vect𝑀\rho_{*}:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathrm{Vect}(M) given by

    (ρ∗​(x))m=dd​t|t=0​ρ​(et​x)​(m).subscriptsubscript𝜌𝑥𝑚evaluated-atdd𝑡𝑡0𝜌superscript𝑒𝑡𝑥𝑚\left(\rho_{*}(x)\right)_{m}=\left.\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}\right|_{t=0}\rho\left(e^{tx}\right)(m).
  5. (v)

    The commutator [ξ,η]𝜉𝜂[\xi,\eta] of two vector fields ξ,η∈Vect​(M)𝜉𝜂Vect𝑀\xi,\eta\in\mathrm{Vect}(M) is the unique vector field that satisfies

    Φξt​Φηs​Φξ−t​Φη−s=Φ[ξ,η]t​s+⋯subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑡𝜉subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑠𝜂subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑡𝜉subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑠𝜂subscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑡𝑠𝜉𝜂⋯\Phi^{t}_{\xi}\Phi^{s}_{\eta}\Phi^{-t}_{\xi}\Phi^{-s}_{\eta}=\Phi^{ts}_{[\xi,\eta]}+\cdots

    where the dots stand for terms of order 3 and higher in s,t𝑠𝑡s,t.

Remark 2.4.1.

To motivate why Vect​(M)=𝔡​𝔦​𝔣​𝔣​(M)Vect𝑀𝔡𝔦𝔣𝔣𝑀\mathrm{Vect}(M)=\mathfrak{diff}(M), we note that 𝔡​𝔦​𝔣​𝔣​(M)𝔡𝔦𝔣𝔣𝑀\mathfrak{diff}(M) should be given by the derivatives of the one-parameter subgroups of Diff​(M)Diff𝑀\mathrm{Diff}(M). If ϕt∈Diff​(M)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡Diff𝑀\phi^{t}\in\mathrm{Diff}(M) is a one-parameter subgroup of M𝑀M, then its derivative defines a vector field ∂t=0ϕt∈Vect​(M)subscript𝑡0superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡Vect𝑀\partial_{t=0}\phi^{t}\in\mathrm{Vect}(M):

dd​t|t=0​ϕt​(m)∈Tm​(M), for ​m∈M.formulae-sequenceevaluated-atdd𝑡𝑡0superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑚subscript𝑇𝑚𝑀 for 𝑚𝑀\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}\Big{|}_{t=0}\phi^{t}(m)\in T_{m}(M),\text{ for }m\in M.

Similarly, to motivate the differential of ρ:G→Diff​(M):𝜌→𝐺Diff𝑀\rho:G\to\mathrm{Diff}(M), we note that ρ𝜌\rho maps one-parameter subgroups to one-parameter subgroups.

Proposition 2.4.1 (Proposition 3.23, [Kir08]).

Let M𝑀M be a smooth manifold and G𝐺G be a Lie group acting smoothly on M𝑀M.

  1. (i)

    The commutator of vector fields makes Vect​(M)Vect𝑀\mathrm{Vect}(M) into a Lie algebra.

    [ξ,η]𝜉𝜂\displaystyle[\xi,\eta] =dd​t​(Φξt)∗​ηabsentdd𝑡subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑡𝜉𝜂\displaystyle=\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}(\Phi^{t}_{\xi})_{*}\eta

Theorem 11 (Theorem 3.25, [Kir08]).

The transformation ρ∗:𝔤→Vect​(M):subscript𝜌→𝔤Vect𝑀\rho_{*}:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathrm{Vect}(M) is a Lie algebra morphism.

Example 2.4.1.
  1. (i)

    Considering the action of G𝐺G on itself by left-multiplication L:G→Diff​(G):𝐿→𝐺Diff𝐺L:G\to\mathrm{Diff}(G), the Lie algebra isomorphism

2.5 Stabilizers and the center

Corollary 2.5.1.

Let f:G1→G2:𝑓→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2f:G_{1}\to G_{2} be a morphism of real or complex Lie groups. Then

  1. (i)

    ker⁡fkernel𝑓\ker f is a closed Lie subgroup with Lie algebra ker⁡f∗kernelsubscript𝑓\ker f_{*}.

  2. (ii)

    The map G1/ker⁡f→Im​f→subscript𝐺1kernel𝑓Im𝑓G_{1}/\ker f\to\mathrm{Im}f is an immersion.

  3. (iii)

    When Im​fIm𝑓\mathrm{Im}f is a submanifold, the map is a G1/ker⁡f→Im​f→subscript𝐺1kernel𝑓Im𝑓G_{1}/\ker f\to\mathrm{Im}f diffeomorphism.

    O​(V,B)={g∈GL⁡(V):B​(g​u,g​v)=B​(u,v)​ for all ​u,v∈V}O𝑉𝐵conditional-set𝑔GL𝑉formulae-sequence𝐵𝑔𝑢𝑔𝑣𝐵𝑢𝑣 for all 𝑢𝑣𝑉\mathrm{O}(V,B)=\left\{g\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V):B(gu,gv)=B(u,v)\text{ for all }u,v\in V\right\}

    𝔬​(V,B)={g∈𝔤​𝔩​(V):B​(x​u,x​v)=B​(u,v)​ for all ​u,v∈V}.𝔬𝑉𝐵conditional-set𝑔𝔤𝔩𝑉formulae-sequence𝐵𝑥𝑢𝑥𝑣𝐵𝑢𝑣 for all 𝑢𝑣𝑉\mathfrak{o}(V,B)=\left\{g\in\mathfrak{gl}(V):B(xu,xv)=B(u,v)\text{ for all }u,v\in V\right\}.

    (ρ∗​(x))B​(u,v)subscriptsubscript𝜌𝑥𝐵𝑢𝑣\displaystyle\left(\rho_{*}(x)\right)_{B}(u,v) =(dd​t|t=0​ρ​(et​x)​B)​(u,v)=(dd​t|t=0​B​(e−t​x​u,e−t​x​v))absentevaluated-atdd𝑡𝑡0𝜌superscript𝑒𝑡𝑥𝐵𝑢𝑣evaluated-atdd𝑡𝑡0𝐵superscript𝑒𝑡𝑥𝑢superscript𝑒𝑡𝑥𝑣\displaystyle=\left(\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}\Big{|}_{t=0}\rho(e^{tx})B\right)(u,v)=\left(\frac{\,\mathrm{d}}{\,\mathrm{d}t}\Big{|}_{t=0}B(e^{-tx}u,e^{-tx}v)\right)
    =−B​(u,x​v)−B​(x​u,v).absent𝐵𝑢𝑥𝑣𝐵𝑥𝑢𝑣\displaystyle=-B(u,xv)-B(xu,v).
  2. (ii)

    Let A𝐴A be a finite-dimensional associative algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}. Then the group of all automorphisms of A𝐴A

    Aut​(A)={g∈GL​(A)∣(g​a)⋅(g​b)=g​(a⋅b)​ for all ​a,b∈A}Aut𝐴conditional-set𝑔GL𝐴formulae-sequence⋅𝑔𝑎𝑔𝑏𝑔⋅𝑎𝑏 for all 𝑎𝑏𝐴\text{Aut}(A)=\{g\in\text{GL}(A)\mid(ga)\cdot(gb)=g(a\cdot b)\text{ for all }a,b\in A\}

    is a Lie group with Lie algebra

    Der(A)={x∈𝔤𝔩(A)∣(x.a)b+a(x.b)=x(ab) for all a,b∈A}\text{Der}(A)=\{x\in\mathfrak{gl}(A)\mid(x.a)b+a(x.b)=x(ab)\text{ for all }a,b\in A\}

    (this Lie algebra is called the algebra of derivations of A𝐴A).

    Indeed, if we consider the space W𝑊W of all linear maps A⊗A→A→tensor-product𝐴𝐴𝐴A\otimes A\to A and define the action of G𝐺G by (g​f)​(a⊗b)=g​f​(g−1​a⊗g−1​b)𝑔𝑓tensor-product𝑎𝑏𝑔𝑓tensor-productsuperscript𝑔1𝑎superscript𝑔1𝑏(gf)(a\otimes b)=gf(g^{-1}a\otimes g^{-1}b) then Aut​A=GμAut𝐴subscript𝐺𝜇\text{Aut}A=G_{\mu}, where μ:A⊗A→A:𝜇→tensor-product𝐴𝐴𝐴\mu:A\otimes A\to A is the multiplication. So Aut​(A)Aut𝐴\text{Aut}(A) is a Lie group with Lie algebra Der​(A)Der𝐴\text{Der}(A).

  3. (iii)

    The same argument also shows that for a finite-dimensional Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}, the group

    Aut​(𝔤)={g∈GL​(𝔤)∣[g​a,g​b]=g​[a,b]​ for all ​a,b∈𝔤}Aut𝔤conditional-set𝑔GL𝔤formulae-sequence𝑔𝑎𝑔𝑏𝑔𝑎𝑏 for all 𝑎𝑏𝔤\text{Aut}(\mathfrak{g})=\{g\in\text{GL}(\mathfrak{g})\mid[ga,gb]=g[a,b]\text{ for all }a,b\in\mathfrak{g}\}

    is a Lie group with Lie algebra

    Der(𝔤)={x∈𝔤𝔩(𝔤)∣[x.a,b]+[a,x.b]=x.[a,b] for all a,b∈𝔤}\text{Der}(\mathfrak{g})=\{x\in\mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})\mid[x.a,b]+[a,x.b]=x.[a,b]\text{ for all }a,b\in\mathfrak{g}\}

    called the Lie algebra of derivations of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

Finally, we can show that the center of G𝐺G is a closed Lie subgroup.

Theorem 12.

Let G𝐺G be a connected Lie group. Then its center Z​(G)𝑍𝐺Z(G) is a closed Lie subgroup with Lie algebra the ideal

𝔷​(𝔤)={x∈𝔤∣[x,y]=0​∀y∈𝔤}.𝔷𝔤conditional-set𝑥𝔤𝑥𝑦0for-all𝑦𝔤\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g})=\{x\in\mathfrak{g}\mid[x,y]=0\ \forall y\in\mathfrak{g}\}.

The quotient group G/Z​(G)𝐺𝑍𝐺G/Z(G) is usually called the adjoint group associated with G𝐺G and denoted Ad​GAd𝐺\text{Ad}\,G:

AdG=G/Z(G)=Im(Ad:G→GL(𝔤))(for connected G).\text{Ad}\,G=G/Z(G)=\text{Im}(\text{Ad}:G\rightarrow\text{GL}(\mathfrak{g}))\quad\text{(for connected }G).

The corresponding Lie algebra is

ad𝔤=𝔤/𝔷(𝔤)=Im(ad:𝔤→𝔤𝔩(𝔤)).\text{ad}\,\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{g}/\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g})=\text{Im}(\text{ad}:\mathfrak{g}\rightarrow\mathfrak{gl}(\mathfrak{g})).

2.6 Campbell–Hausdorff formula

So far, we have shown that the multiplication in a Lie group G𝐺G defines the commutator in g=T1​G𝑔subscript𝑇1𝐺g=T_{1}G. However, the definition of commutator only used the lowest non-trivial term of the group law in logarithmic coordinates. Thus, it might be expected that higher terms give more operations on g. However, it turns out that it is not so: the whole group law is completely determined by the lowest term, i.e. by the commutator, as follows from the Campbell–Hausdorff formula:

Theorem 13 (Campbell–Hausdorff Formula).

For small enough x,y∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝔤x,y\in\mathfrak{g} one has

exp⁡(x)​exp⁡(y)=exp⁡(μ​(x,y))𝑥𝑦𝜇𝑥𝑦\exp(x)\exp(y)=\exp(\mu(x,y))

for some 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}-valued function μ​(x,y)𝜇𝑥𝑦\mu(x,y) which is given by the following series convergent in some neighborhood of (0,0)00(0,0):

μ​(x,y)=x+y+∑n≥2μn​(x,y),𝜇𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦subscript𝑛2subscript𝜇𝑛𝑥𝑦\mu(x,y)=x+y+\sum_{n\geq 2}\mu_{n}(x,y),

where μn​(x,y)subscript𝜇𝑛𝑥𝑦\mu_{n}(x,y) is a Lie polynomial in x,y𝑥𝑦x,y of degree n𝑛n, i.e. an expression consisting of commutators of x,y𝑥𝑦x,y, their commutators, etc., of total degree n𝑛n in x,y𝑥𝑦x,y. This expression is universal: it does not depend on the Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} or on the choice of x,y𝑥𝑦x,y. In particular, the group operation in a connected Lie group G𝐺G can be recovered from the commutator in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

It is possible to write the expression for μ𝜇\mu explicitly. However, this is rarely useful, so we will only write the first few terms:

μ​(x,y)=x+y+12​[x,y]+112​([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]])+⋯𝜇𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦12𝑥𝑦112𝑥𝑥𝑦𝑦𝑦𝑥⋯\mu(x,y)=x+y+\frac{1}{2}[x,y]+\frac{1}{12}\left([x,[x,y]]+[y,[y,x]]\right)+\cdots

Although it follows from the Campbell–Hausdorff formula, the commutation criterion of the exponential can be also proven directly:

Theorem 14 (Theorem 3.36, [Kir08]).

Let x,y∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝔤x,y\in\mathfrak{g}. Then ex​ey=ey​exsuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x} if and only if [x,y]=0𝑥𝑦0[x,y]=0. In that case ex​ey=ey​ex=ex+ysuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑥𝑦e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x}=e^{x+y}.

Proof.

The if direction follows from the definition of the commutator via Taylor series. For the other direction we follow the method suggested in Exercise 3.11 of [Kir08]:

Ad⁡(ex)​y=ead⁡x​y=∑n≥0(ad⁡x)nn!​y=yAdsuperscript𝑒𝑥𝑦superscript𝑒ad𝑥𝑦subscript𝑛0superscriptad𝑥𝑛𝑛𝑦𝑦\operatorname{Ad}(e^{x})y=e^{\operatorname{ad}x}y=\sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{(\operatorname{ad}x)^{n}}{n!}y=y

But Cg​ez=eAdg⁡zsubscript𝐶𝑔superscript𝑒𝑧superscript𝑒subscriptAd𝑔𝑧C_{g}e^{z}=e^{\operatorname{Ad}_{g}z}, so the above implies that ex​ey​e−x=Cex​ey=eAd⁡(ex)​y=eysuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝐶superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒Adsuperscript𝑒𝑥𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦e^{x}e^{y}e^{-x}=C_{e^{x}}e^{y}=e^{\operatorname{Ad}(e^{x})y}=e^{y}. ∎

2.7 Fundamental theorems of Lie theory

Let us summarize the results we have so far about the relation between Lie groups and Lie algebras.

  1. 1.

    Every real or complex Lie group G𝐺G defines a Lie algebra 𝔤=T1​G𝔤subscript𝑇1𝐺\mathfrak{g}=T_{1}G (respectively, real or complex), with commutator defined by (3.2); we will write 𝔤=Lie​(G)𝔤Lie𝐺\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G). Every morphism of Lie groups φ:G1→G2:𝜑→subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2\varphi:G_{1}\to G_{2} defines a morphism of Lie algebras φ∗:𝔤1→𝔤2:subscript𝜑→subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\varphi_{*}:\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}. For connected G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}, the map

    Hom​(G1,G2)→Hom​(𝔤1,𝔤2)→Homsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2Homsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})\to\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2})
    φ↦φ∗maps-to𝜑subscript𝜑\varphi\mapsto\varphi_{*}

    is injective. (Here Hom​(𝔤1,𝔤2)Homsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}) is the set of Lie algebra morphisms.)

  2. 2.

    As a special case of the previous, every Lie subgroup H⊂G𝐻𝐺H\subset G defines a Lie subalgebra 𝔥⊂𝔤𝔥𝔤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}.

  3. 3.

    The group law in a connected Lie group G𝐺G can be recovered from the commutator in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}; however, we do not yet know whether we can also recover the topology of G𝐺G from 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

However, this still leaves a number of questions.

Question 1.

Given a morphism of Lie algebras 𝔤1→𝔤2→subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}, where 𝔤1=Lie​(G1)subscript𝔤1Liesubscript𝐺1\mathfrak{g}_{1}=\text{Lie}(G_{1}), 𝔤2=Lie​(G2)subscript𝔤2Liesubscript𝐺2\mathfrak{g}_{2}=\text{Lie}(G_{2}), can this morphism always be lifted to a morphism of the Lie groups?

Question 2.

Given a Lie subalgebra 𝔥⊂𝔤=Lie​(G)𝔥𝔤Lie𝐺\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}=\text{Lie}(G), does there always exist a corresponding Lie subgroup H⊂G𝐻𝐺H\subset G?

Question 3.

Can every Lie algebra be obtained as a Lie algebra of a Lie group?

As the following example shows, in this form the answer to question 1 is negative.

Example 2.7.1.

Let G1=S1=ℝ/ℤ,G2=ℝformulae-sequencesubscript𝐺1superscript𝑆1ℝℤsubscript𝐺2ℝG_{1}=S^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z},G_{2}=\mathbb{R}. Then the Lie algebras are 𝔤1=𝔤2=ℝsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2ℝ\mathfrak{g}_{1}=\mathfrak{g}_{2}=\mathbb{R} with zero commutator. Consider the identity map 𝔤1→𝔤2:a↦a:→subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2maps-to𝑎𝑎\mathfrak{g}_{1}\to\mathfrak{g}_{2}:a\mapsto a. Then the lift f~:ℝ→ℝ:~𝑓→ℝℝ\tilde{f}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} of the corresponding morphism to the universal covering group (provided that the underlying morphism f:𝕊1→ℝ:𝑓→superscript𝕊1ℝf:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\mathbb{R} exists), should be given by (~θ)=θ+c\tilde{(}\theta)=\theta+c; on the other hand, it must also satisfy f~​(ℤ)={0}~𝑓ℤ0\tilde{f}(\mathbb{Z})=\{0\}. Thus, this morphism of Lie algebras can not be lifted to a morphism of Lie groups.

In this example the difficulty arose because G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} was not simply-connected. It turns out that this is the only difficulty: after taking care of this, the answers to all the questions posed above are positive. The following theorems give precise statements.

Theorem 15 (First fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

For any real or complex Lie group G𝐺G, there is a bijection between connected Lie subgroups H⊂G𝐻𝐺H\subset G and Lie subalgebras 𝔥⊂𝔤𝔥𝔤\mathfrak{h}\subset\mathfrak{g}, given by H↦𝔥=Lie​(H)=T1​Hmaps-to𝐻𝔥Lie𝐻subscript𝑇1𝐻H\mapsto\mathfrak{h}=\text{Lie}(H)=T_{1}H.

Theorem 16 (Second fundemental theorem of Lie theory).

If G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2} are Lie groups (real or complex) and G1subscript𝐺1G_{1} is connected and simply connected, then Hom​(G1,G2)=Hom​(𝔤1,𝔤2)Homsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2Homsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\text{Hom}(G_{1},G_{2})=\text{Hom}(\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2}), where 𝔤1,𝔤2subscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\mathfrak{g}_{1},\mathfrak{g}_{2} are Lie algebras of G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2} respectively.

Theorem 17 (Lie’s third theorem).

Any finite-dimensional real or complex Lie algebra is isomorphic to a Lie algebra of a Lie group (respectively, real or complex).

These are the fundamental theorems of Lie theory and combining these with the previous results, we get the following important corollary.

Corollary 2.7.1 (Le group and algebra equivalence).

The categories of finite-dimensional Lie algebras and connected, simply-connected Lie groups are equivalent. In other words, for any real or complex finite-dimensional Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) connected simply-connected Lie group G𝐺G (respectively, real or complex) with Lie​(G)=𝔤Lie𝐺𝔤\text{Lie}(G)=\mathfrak{g}. Any other connected Lie group G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} must be of the form G/Z𝐺𝑍G/Z for some discrete central subgroup Z⊂G𝑍𝐺Z\subset G.

2.8 Complex and real forms

The operation of complexification, which is trivial at the level of Lie algebras, is highly non-trivial at the level of Lie groups. Real forms and their complexifications can be topologically quite different: for example, SU⁡(n)SU𝑛\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(n) is compact while SL⁡(n,C)SL𝑛𝐶\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,C) is not. On the other hand, it is natural to expect that their algebras share many algebraic properties, such as semisimplicity. Thus we may use the properties of the complex Lie algebra to study the real Lie algebra, and vice versa, or use the properties of one real form to study another real form. Thus, we may use, for example, use the compact group SU⁡(n)SU𝑛\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(n) to prove some results about the non-compact group SL⁡(n,C)SL𝑛𝐶\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,C). Moreover, since 𝔰​𝔩​(n,ℝ)ℂ=𝔰​𝔩​(n,ℂ)𝔰𝔩subscript𝑛ℝℂ𝔰𝔩𝑛ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{R})_{\mathbb{C}}=\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{C}), this will also give us results about the non-compact real group SL⁡(n,ℝ)SL𝑛ℝ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,\mathbb{R}).

Definition 2.8.1.
  1. (i)

    The complexification 𝔤ℂsubscript𝔤ℂ\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}} of a real Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is the complex Lie algebra

    𝔤ℂ​=def​𝔤⊗ℝℂ=𝔤⊕i​𝔤.subscripttensor-productℝsubscript𝔤ℂdef𝔤ℂdirect-sum𝔤𝑖𝔤\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\mathfrak{g}\otimes_{\mathbb{R}}\mathbb{C}=\mathfrak{g}\oplus i\mathfrak{g}.

    We say that 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a real form of 𝔤ℂsubscript𝔤ℂ\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}}.

  2. (ii)

    Let G𝐺G be a connected complex Lie group with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. A closed real Lie subgroup K≤G𝐾𝐺K\leq G is a real form of G𝐺G if its Lie algebra 𝔨𝔨\mathfrak{k} is a real form of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

In some cases, complexification is obvious, as in 𝔤=s​l​(n,R)𝔤𝑠𝑙𝑛𝑅\mathfrak{g}=sl(n,R). Others however, are less obvious, as 𝔤=𝔲​(n)𝔤𝔲𝑛\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{u}(n). Finding a real form for a complex group is can be often direct:

Proposition 2.8.1.

Let G𝐺G be a connected simply-connected complex Lie group with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then every real form 𝔨𝔨\mathfrak{k} of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is realised as the Lie algebra of a real form K𝐾K of G𝐺G.

Proof.

Considering 𝔤=𝔨⊕i​𝔨𝔤direct-sum𝔨𝑖𝔨\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{k}\oplus i\mathfrak{k}, we define the real Lie algebra automorphism

θ:𝔤→𝔤,x+i​y↦x−i​y.:𝜃formulae-sequence→𝔤𝔤maps-to𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑥𝑖𝑦\theta:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{g},\quad x+iy\mapsto x-iy.

Since G𝐺G is connected and simply connected, the second fundamental theorem of Lie groups tells us that θ𝜃\theta can be lifted to a Lie group automorphism Θ:G→G:Θ→𝐺𝐺\Theta:G\to G. Then K=GΘ𝐾superscript𝐺ΘK=G^{\Theta} is a real form of G𝐺G with Lie algebra ker⁡θ=𝔨kernel𝜃𝔨\ker\theta=\mathfrak{k}. ∎

Going in the opposite direction, from a real Lie group to a complex one, is more subtle: there are real Lie groups that can not be obtained as real forms of a complex Lie group (for example, it is known that the universal cover of SL⁡(2,ℝ)SL2ℝ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(2,\mathbb{R}) is not a real form of any complex Lie group). It is still possible to define a complexification for any real Lie group G; however, in general the former does not admit the latter as a subgroup.

Chapter 3 Representations of Lie groups and Lie algebras

In this chapter, we will discuss the representation theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras. Unless specified otherwise, all Lie groups, algebras, and representations are finite-dimensional, and all representations are complex. Lie groups and Lie algebras can be either real or complex; unless specified otherwise, all results are valid both for the real and complex case.

3.1 Basic definitions

Definition 3.1.1.

A representation of a Lie group G𝐺G is a vector space V𝑉V together with a morphism ρ:G→GL​(V):𝜌→𝐺GL𝑉\rho:G\to\mathrm{GL}(V).

A representation of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a vector space V𝑉V together with a morphism ρ:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩​(V):𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V).

A morphism between two representations V,W𝑉𝑊V,W of the same group G𝐺G is a linear map f:V→W:𝑓→𝑉𝑊f:V\to W which commutes with the action of G𝐺G: f​ρ​(g)=ρ​(g)​f𝑓𝜌𝑔𝜌𝑔𝑓f\rho(g)=\rho(g)f. In a similar way, one defines a morphism of representations of a Lie algebra. The space of all G𝐺G-morphisms (respectively, 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}-morphisms) between V𝑉V and W𝑊W will be denoted by HomG​(V,W)subscriptHom𝐺𝑉𝑊\mathrm{Hom}_{G}(V,W) (respectively, Hom𝔤​(V,W)subscriptHom𝔤𝑉𝑊\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathfrak{g}}(V,W)).

Remark 3.1.1.

Morphisms between representations are also frequently called intertwining operators because they “intertwine” action of G𝐺G in V𝑉V and W𝑊W.

The notion of a representation is completely parallel to the notion of module over an associative ring or algebra; the difference of terminology is due to historical reasons. In fact, it is also usual to use the word “module” rather than “representation” for Lie algebras: a module over Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is the same as a representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. We will use both terms interchangeably.

Note that in this definition we did not specify whether V𝑉V and G𝐺G are real or complex. Usually if G𝐺G (respectively, 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}) is complex, then V𝑉V should also be taken a complex vector space. However, it also makes sense to take complex V𝑉V even if G𝐺G is real: in this case we require that the morphism G→GL​(V)→𝐺GL𝑉G\to\mathrm{GL}(V) be smooth, considering GL​(V)GL𝑉\mathrm{GL}(V) as 2​n22superscript𝑛22n^{2}-dimensional real manifold. Similarly, for real Lie algebras we can consider complex representations requiring that ρ:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩​(V):𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V) be ℝℝ\mathbb{R}-linear.

Of course, we could also restrict ourselves to consideration of real representations of real groups. However, it turns out that the introduction of complex representations significantly simplifies the theory even for real groups and algebras. Thus, from now on, all representations will be complex unless specified otherwise.

Example 3.1.1.

For a Lie group G𝐺G or a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} we always have the following two representations:

  1. (i)

    Trivial representation: V=ℂ,ρ​(g)=idformulae-sequence𝑉ℂ𝜌𝑔idV=\mathbb{C},\rho(g)=\operatorname{id} for all g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G (respectively ρ​(x)=0𝜌𝑥0\rho(x)=0 for all x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}).

  2. (ii)

    Adjoint representation: V=𝔤,ρ​(g)=Adgformulae-sequence𝑉𝔤𝜌𝑔subscriptAd𝑔V=\mathfrak{g},\rho(g)=\operatorname{Ad}_{g} for all g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G (respectively ρ​(x)=adx𝜌𝑥subscriptad𝑥\rho(x)=\operatorname{ad}_{x} for all x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}).

  3. (iii)

    Coadjoint representation: V=𝔤∗,ρ​(x)=adx∗formulae-sequence𝑉superscript𝔤𝜌𝑥superscriptsubscriptad𝑥V=\mathfrak{g}^{*},\rho(x)=\operatorname{ad}_{x}^{*} for all x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}.

The first important result about representations of Lie groups and Lie algebras is the following theorem. It tells us that from a representation (or a morphism of representations) of a Lie group we can obtain a representation (or a morphism of representations) of its Lie algebra, and that when G𝐺G is connected, simply connected, then representing G𝐺G and representing its Lie algebra is equivalent.

Theorem 18.

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group (real or complex) with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

  1. 1.

    Every representation ρ:G→GL​(V):𝜌→𝐺GL𝑉\rho:G\to\mathrm{GL}(V) defines a representation ρ∗:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩​(V):subscript𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho_{*}:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V), and every morphism of representations of G𝐺G is automatically a morphism of representations of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

  2. 2.

    If G𝐺G is connected, simply-connected, then ρ↦ρ∗maps-to𝜌subscript𝜌\rho\mapsto\rho_{*} gives an equivalence of categories of representations of G𝐺G and representations of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. In particular, every representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} can be uniquely lifted to a representation of G𝐺G, and HomG​(V,W)=Hom𝔤​(V,W)subscriptHom𝐺𝑉𝑊subscriptHom𝔤𝑉𝑊\mathrm{Hom}_{G}(V,W)=\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathfrak{g}}(V,W).

This is an important result, as Lie algebras are, after all, finite dimensional vector spaces, so they are easier to deal with.

Example 3.1.2.

A representation of SU​(2)SU2\mathrm{SU}(2) is the same as a representation of 𝔰​𝔲​(2)𝔰𝔲2\mathfrak{su}(2), i.e. a vector space with three endomorphisms X,Y,Z𝑋𝑌𝑍X,Y,Z, satisfying commutation relations X​Y−Y​X=Z,Y​Z−Z​Y=X,Z​X−X​Z=Yformulae-sequence𝑋𝑌𝑌𝑋𝑍formulae-sequence𝑌𝑍𝑍𝑌𝑋𝑍𝑋𝑋𝑍𝑌XY-YX=Z,YZ-ZY=X,ZX-XZ=Y.

Remark 3.1.2.

This theorem can also be used to describe representations of a group which is connected but not simply-connected, in the sense that representations of G𝐺G are the same as representations of its universal cover that are trivial over the fundamentla group of G𝐺G. More concretely, any such group G𝐺G can be written as G=G~/Z𝐺~𝐺𝑍G=\tilde{G}/Z for some simply-connected group G~~𝐺\tilde{G} and a discrete central subgroup Z⊂G𝑍𝐺Z\subset G. Thus, representations of G𝐺G are the same as representations of G~~𝐺\tilde{G} satisfying ρ​(Z)=id𝜌𝑍id\rho(Z)=\mathrm{id}. An important example of this is when G=SO​(3,ℝ)𝐺SO3ℝG=\mathrm{SO}(3,\mathbb{R}), G~=SU​(2)~𝐺SU2\tilde{G}=\mathrm{SU}(2).

Lemma 3.1.1.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a real Lie algebra and 𝔤ℂsubscript𝔤ℂ\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}} its complexification. Then the categories of complex representations of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} and 𝔤ℂsubscript𝔤ℂ\mathfrak{g}_{\mathbb{C}} are equivalent.

The next example shows that we can reduce the problem of study of representations of a non-compact Lie group SL⁡(2,ℂ)SL2ℂ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(2,\mathbb{C}) to

Example 3.1.3.

The categories of finite-dimensional representations of SL⁡(2,ℂ)SL2ℂ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(2,\mathbb{C}), SU⁡(2)SU2\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2), 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) and 𝔰​𝔲⁡(2)𝔰𝔲2\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(2) are all equivalent. Indeed, 𝔰​𝔩​(2,C)=(𝔰​𝔲⁡(2))ℂ𝔰𝔩2𝐶subscript𝔰𝔲2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,C)=(\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(2))_{\mathbb{C}} , so categories of their finite-dimensional representations are equivalent; since the groups SU⁡(2),SL⁡(2,C)SU2SL2𝐶\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2),\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(2,C) are simply-connected, they have the same representations as the corresponding Lie algebras.

3.2 Operations on representations

3.2.1 Subrepresentations and quotients

Definition 3.2.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of G𝐺G (respectively 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}). A subrepresentation is a vector subspace W⊆V𝑊𝑉W\subseteq V stable under the action: ρ​(g)​W⊆W𝜌𝑔𝑊𝑊\rho(g)W\subseteq W for all g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G (respectively, ρ​(x)​W⊆W𝜌𝑥𝑊𝑊\rho(x)W\subseteq W for all x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g}).

When W⊆V𝑊𝑉W\subseteq V is a subrepresentation, then one can obtain the factor representation or quotient representation V/W𝑉𝑊V/W given by

ρV/W​(g)=ρV​(g)+W.subscript𝜌𝑉𝑊𝑔subscript𝜌𝑉𝑔𝑊\rho_{V/W}(g)=\rho_{V}(g)+W.
