3.2.3 Invariants

Definition 3.2.2.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of a Lie group G𝐺G. A vector v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V is called invariant if ρ​(g)​v=v𝜌𝑔𝑣𝑣\rho(g)v=v for all g∈G𝑔𝐺g\in G. The subspace of invariant vectors in V𝑉V is denoted by VGsuperscript𝑉𝐺V^{G}. Similarly, let V𝑉V be a representation of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. A vector v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V is called invariant if ρ​(x)​v=0𝜌𝑥𝑣0\rho(x)v=0 for all x∈g𝑥𝑔x\in g. The subspace of invariant vectors in V𝑉V is denoted by V𝔤superscript𝑉𝔤V^{\mathfrak{g}} .

Remark 3.2.1.

When G𝐺G is connected, and V𝑉V is a representation of G𝐺G, then

VG=V𝔤superscript𝑉𝐺superscript𝑉𝔤V^{G}=V^{\mathfrak{g}}
Example 3.2.2.
  1. (i)

    hom⁡(V,W)hom𝑉𝑊\hom(V,W): Considering hom⁡(V,W)hom𝑉𝑊\hom(V,W) as the representation arising from two representations V,W𝑉𝑊V,W, we have hom(V,W)G=homG(V,W)\hom(V,W)^{G}=\hom_{G}(V,W).

  2. (ii)

    Bilinear forms: We have B∈VG𝐵superscript𝑉𝐺B\in V^{G} if and only if the linear map V→V∗→𝑉superscript𝑉V\to V^{*}, given by v→B​(v,−)→𝑣𝐵𝑣v\to B(v,-), is a representations morphism.

3.3 Irreducible representations

One of the main problems of the representation theory is the problem of classi- fication of all representations of a Lie group or a Lie algebra. In this generality, it is an extremely difficult problem and for a general Lie group, no satisfactory answer is known. We will later show that for some special classes of Lie groups (namely compact Lie groups and semisimple Lie groups, to be defined later) this problem does have a good answer. The most natural approach to this problem is to start by studying the sim- plest possible representations, which would serve as building blocks for more complicated representations.

Definition 3.3.1.
  1. (i)

    A non-zero representation V of G𝐺G or 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is called irreducible or simple if it has no subrepresentations other than 00 and V𝑉V . Otherwise V𝑉V is called reducible.

  2. (ii)

    V𝑉V is a completely completely reducible or semisimple representation if it is isomorphic to a direct sum of irreducible representations: V=⊕iVi𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖V=\oplus_{i}V_{i}, with Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} irreducible.

  3. (iii)

    If V𝑉V is completely reducible, one usually groups together isomorphic summands writing V=⊕ini​Vi𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖V=\oplus_{i}n_{i}V_{i}, where Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} are pair-wise non-isomorphic irreducible representations and the numbers nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are called multiplicities.

Remark 3.3.1.

Sometimes, it will be useful to consider the isomorphic expressions:

n​V≃⊕1nV≃ℂn⊗Vsimilar-to-or-equals𝑛𝑉superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum1𝑛𝑉similar-to-or-equalstensor-productsuperscriptℂ𝑛𝑉nV\simeq\oplus_{1}^{n}V\simeq\mathbb{C}^{n}\otimes V

where the latter isomorphism is given by the map (v1,⋯,vn)↦e1⊗v1+⋯​en⊗vnmaps-tosubscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑛tensor-productsubscript𝑒1subscript𝑣1tensor-product⋯subscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛(v_{1},\cdots,v_{n})\mapsto e_{1}\otimes v_{1}+\cdots e_{n}\otimes v_{n} and in the other direction by the map z⊗v↤(z1​v,⋯,zn​v)↤tensor-product𝑧𝑣subscript𝑧1𝑣⋯subscript𝑧𝑛𝑣z\otimes v\mapsfrom(z_{1}v,\cdots,z_{n}v).

Thus, more modest goals of the representation theory would be answering the following questions:

  1. (i)

    For a given Lie group G𝐺G, classify all irreducible representations of G.

  2. (ii)

    For a given representation V𝑉V of a Lie group G, given that it is completely reducible, find explicitly the decomposition of V𝑉V into direct sum of irreducibles.

  3. (iii)

    For which Lie groups G𝐺G all representations are completely reducible?

Example 3.3.1 (Irreducible representations).
  1. (i)

    ℂnsuperscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n}: It is irreducible as a representation of SL⁡(n,ℂ),GL⁡(n,ℂ)SL𝑛ℂGL𝑛ℂ\operatorname{{\mathrm{SL}}}(n,\mathbb{C}),\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(n,\mathbb{C}).

Example 3.3.2 (Reducible representations).
  1. (i)

    ℝℝ\mathbb{R}: It is reducible but not completely reducible as a representation of ℝℝ\mathbb{R} (either seen as a group, or a Lie algebra).

  2. (ii)

    ℂn⊗ℂntensor-productsuperscriptℂ𝑛superscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n}\otimes\mathbb{C}^{n}: It is completely reducible as a representation of GL⁡(n,ℂ)GL𝑛ℂ\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(n,\mathbb{C}), since ℂn⊗ℂn=S2​ℂn⊕Λ2​ℂntensor-productsuperscriptℂ𝑛superscriptℂ𝑛direct-sumsuperscript𝑆2superscriptℂ𝑛superscriptΛ2superscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n}\otimes\mathbb{C}^{n}=S^{2}\mathbb{C}^{n}\oplus\Lambda^{2}\mathbb{C}^{n}, where S2​ℂnsuperscript𝑆2superscriptℂ𝑛S^{2}\mathbb{C}^{n} is the symmetric tensor product and Λ2​ℂnsuperscriptΛ2superscriptℂ𝑛\Lambda^{2}\mathbb{C}^{n} is the antisymmetric tensor product.

  3. (iii)

    Unitary representations are completely irreducible (see Theorem 19). This includes in particular representations of compact groups (see Theorem 22).

  4. (iv)

    𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}): Putting aside that we can classify all its finite-dimensional representations: any representation of V𝑉V is completely reducible, and any irreducible representation is isomorphic to a highest weight representation (see LABEL:thm:irreducible_representations_of_sl2).

Proof.
  1. (i)

    Looking at the Lie algebra 𝔤=ℝ𝔤ℝ\mathfrak{g}=\mathbb{R}, representations on V𝑉V are linear maps ρ∗:ℝ→𝔤​𝔩​(V):subscript𝜌→ℝ𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho_{*}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V) who will have the form t↦t​Amaps-to𝑡𝑡𝐴t\mapsto tA, where A=ρ∗​(1)𝐴subscript𝜌1A=\rho_{*}(1). Hence representations of G=ℝ𝐺ℝG=\mathbb{R} are the Lie group morphisms ℝ→GL⁡(d,ℂ)→ℝGL𝑑ℂ\mathbb{R}\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(d,\mathbb{C}) that have the form t↦et​Amaps-to𝑡superscript𝑒𝑡𝐴t\mapsto e^{tA}, where A=ρ∗​(1)∈𝔤​𝔩​(ℂ,d)𝐴subscript𝜌1𝔤𝔩ℂ𝑑A=\rho_{*}(1)\in\mathfrak{gl}(\mathbb{C},d). If v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V is an eigenvector of A𝐴A, then ℂ​vℂ𝑣\mathbb{C}v is a subrepresentation in V𝑉V, so the only irreducible representations of ℝℝ\mathbb{R} are one-dimensional. In fact, t↦et​Amaps-to𝑡superscript𝑒𝑡𝐴t\mapsto e^{tA} is completely irreducible if and only if A𝐴A is diagonalizable. Hence, the irreducible ones are given as the linear maps ρ∗:ℝ→𝔤𝔩(V)≃ℂ,t↦tλ\rho_{*}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V)\simeq\mathbb{C},t\mapsto t\lambda, for some λ=λρ∗∈ℂ𝜆subscript𝜆subscript𝜌ℂ\lambda=\lambda_{\rho_{*}}\in\mathbb{C}, and the corresponding representation of G𝐺G is given by ρ:ℝ→GL(V)≃ℂ×,t↦et​λ\rho:\mathbb{R}\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V)\simeq\mathbb{C}^{\times},t\mapsto e^{t\lambda}.

∎

One tool which can be used in decomposing representations into direct sum is the use of central elements.

Lemma 3.3.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of a Lie group G𝐺G (or a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} respectively).

  1. (i)

    Let A∈homG⁡(V,V)𝐴subscripthom𝐺𝑉𝑉A\in\hom_{G}(V,V) be a diagonalizable interwining operator. Then each eigenspace Vλsubscript𝑉𝜆V_{\lambda} of A𝐴A is an invariant subspace and we have the decomposition V=⊕Vλ𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑉𝜆V=\oplus V_{\lambda} into subrepresentations.

  2. (ii)

    If Z∈Z​(G)𝑍𝑍𝐺Z\in Z(G) is a central element such that ρ​(Z)𝜌𝑍\rho(Z) is diagonalizable, then as a representation of G𝐺G, V𝑉V decomposes into a direct sum of eigenspaces of ρ​(Z)𝜌𝑍\rho(Z): V=⊕Vλ𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑉𝜆V=\oplus V_{\lambda}.

Of course, there is no guarantee that Vλsubscript𝑉𝜆V_{\lambda} will be an irreducible representation; moreover, in many cases the Lie groups we consider have no central elements at all.

3.4 Intertwining operators and Schur’s lemma

In this section we consider the following questions:

Question 4.

How can G𝐺G-invariance of an operator A∈𝔤​𝔩​(V)𝐴𝔤𝔩𝑉A\in\mathfrak{gl}(V) helps computing eigenvalues and eigenspaces?

Question 5.

What is an easy way to compute the centre of classical Lie groups?

The following Lemma can be seen as a way to answer these questions:

Lemma 3.4.1 (Schur’s lemma).
  1. (i)

    Let V𝑉V be an irreducible representation of a Lie group G𝐺G (similar result holds for representations of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.). Then the space of intertwining operators is one-dimensional:

    homG⁡(V,V)=ℂ​id.subscripthom𝐺𝑉𝑉ℂid\hom_{G}(V,V)=\mathbb{C}\operatorname{id}.
  2. (ii)

    Let V,W𝑉𝑊V,W be irreducible representations of a Lie group G𝐺G which are not isomorphic. Then homG⁡(V,W)=0subscripthom𝐺𝑉𝑊0\hom_{G}(V,W)=0.

Example 3.4.1 (Answer to 5).

Consider the group GL​(n,ℂ)GL𝑛ℂ\mathrm{GL}(n,\mathbb{C}). Since ℂnsuperscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n} is irreducible as a representation of GL​(n,ℂ)GL𝑛ℂ\mathrm{GL}(n,\mathbb{C}), every operator commuting with GL​(n,ℂ)GL𝑛ℂ\mathrm{GL}(n,\mathbb{C}) must be scalar. Thus, the center Z​(GL​(n,ℂ))={λ⋅id,λ∈ℂ×}𝑍GL𝑛ℂ⋅𝜆id𝜆superscriptℂZ(\mathrm{GL}(n,\mathbb{C}))=\{\lambda\cdot\mathrm{id},\lambda\in\mathbb{C}^{\times}\}; similarly, the center of the Lie algebra is Z​(𝔤​𝔩​(n,ℂ))={λ⋅id,λ∈ℂ}𝑍𝔤𝔩𝑛ℂ⋅𝜆id𝜆ℂZ(\mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb{C}))=\{\lambda\cdot\mathrm{id},\lambda\in\mathbb{C}\}.

Since ℂnsuperscriptℂ𝑛\mathbb{C}^{n} is also irreducible as a representation of SL​(n,ℂ)SL𝑛ℂ\mathrm{SL}(n,\mathbb{C}), U​(n)U𝑛\mathrm{U}(n), SU​(n)SU𝑛\mathrm{SU}(n), SO​(n,ℂ)SO𝑛ℂ\mathrm{SO}(n,\mathbb{C}), a similar argument can be used to compute the center of each of these groups. The answer is

Z​(SL​(n,ℂ))=Z​(SU​(n))={λ⋅id,λn=1}𝔷​(U​(n))={λ⋅id,|λ|=1}Z​(𝔰​𝔩​(n,ℂ))=Z​(𝔰​𝔲​(n))=0𝔷​(𝔲​(n))={λ⋅id,λ∈i​ℝ}Z​(SO​(n,ℂ))=Z​(SO​(n,ℝ))={±1}𝔷​(𝔰​𝔬​(n,ℂ))=𝔷​(𝔰​𝔬​(n,ℝ))=0.𝑍SL𝑛ℂ𝑍SU𝑛⋅𝜆idsuperscript𝜆𝑛1𝔷U𝑛⋅𝜆id𝜆1𝑍𝔰𝔩𝑛ℂ𝑍𝔰𝔲𝑛0𝔷𝔲𝑛⋅𝜆id𝜆𝑖ℝ𝑍SO𝑛ℂ𝑍SO𝑛ℝplus-or-minus1𝔷𝔰𝔬𝑛ℂ𝔷𝔰𝔬𝑛ℝ0\begin{array}[]{ll}Z(\mathrm{SL}(n,\mathbb{C}))=Z(\mathrm{SU}(n))=\{\lambda\cdot\mathrm{id},\,\lambda^{n}=1\}&\mathfrak{z}(\mathrm{U}(n))=\{\lambda\cdot\mathrm{id},\,|\lambda|=1\}\\ Z(\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{C}))=Z(\mathfrak{su}(n))=0&\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{u}(n))=\{\lambda\cdot\mathrm{id},\,\lambda\in i\mathbb{R}\}\\ Z(\mathrm{SO}(n,\mathbb{C}))=Z(\mathrm{SO}(n,\mathbb{R}))=\{\pm 1\}&\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{so}(n,\mathbb{C}))=\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{so}(n,\mathbb{R}))=0.\end{array}

To answer 4, we can use the following corollary of Schur’s lemma:

Corollary 3.4.1.

Let V𝑉V be a completely reducible representation of Lie group G𝐺G (respectively, Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}). Then

  1. 1.

    If V=⨁Vi𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑉𝑖V=\bigoplus V_{i}, Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} irreducible, pairwise non-isomorphic, then any intertwining operator Φ:V→V:Φ→𝑉𝑉\Phi:V\to V is of the form Φ=⨁λi​idViΦdirect-sumsubscript𝜆𝑖subscriptidsubscript𝑉𝑖\Phi=\bigoplus\lambda_{i}\mathrm{id}_{V_{i}}.

  2. 2.

    If V=⨁ni​Vi=⨁ni​ℂni⊗Vi𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖direct-sumtensor-productsubscript𝑛𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖V=\bigoplus n_{i}V_{i}=\bigoplus n_{i}\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}}\otimes V_{i}, Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} irreducible, pairwise non-isomorphic, then any intertwining operator Φ:V→V:Φ→𝑉𝑉\Phi:V\to V is of the form Φ=⨁(Ai⊗idVi)Φdirect-sumtensor-productsubscript𝐴𝑖subscriptidsubscript𝑉𝑖\Phi=\bigoplus(A_{i}\otimes\mathrm{id}_{V_{i}}), where Ai∈End​(ℂni)subscript𝐴𝑖Endsuperscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑖A_{i}\in\mathrm{End}(\mathbb{C}^{n_{i}}).

Proof.

For part (1), notice that any operator V→V→𝑉𝑉V\to V can be written in a block form: Φ=⨁Φi​j,Φi​j:Vi→Vj:Φdirect-sumsubscriptΦ𝑖𝑗subscriptΦ𝑖𝑗→subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑗\Phi=\bigoplus\Phi_{ij},\Phi_{ij}:V_{i}\to V_{j}. By Schur’s lemma, Φi​j=0subscriptΦ𝑖𝑗0\Phi_{ij}=0 for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j and Φi​i=λi​idVisubscriptΦ𝑖𝑖subscript𝜆𝑖subscriptidsubscript𝑉𝑖\Phi_{ii}=\lambda_{i}\mathrm{id}_{V_{i}}. Part (2) is proved similarly. ∎

This result shows that indeed, if we can decompose a representation V𝑉V into irreducible ones, this will give us a very effective tool for analyzing intertwining operators. For example, if V=⨁Vi,Vi≠Vjformulae-sequence𝑉direct-sumsubscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑗V=\bigoplus V_{i},V_{i}\neq V_{j}, then Φ=⨁λi​idViΦdirect-sumsubscript𝜆𝑖subscriptidsubscript𝑉𝑖\Phi=\bigoplus\lambda_{i}\mathrm{id}_{V_{i}}, so one can find λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} by computing Φ​(v)Φ𝑣\Phi(v) for just one vector in Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}. It also shows that each eigenvalue λisubscript𝜆𝑖\lambda_{i} will appear with multiplicity equal to dimVidimensionsubscript𝑉𝑖\dim V_{i}. This is exactly what we did in the baby example above, only now Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} was one-dimensional, where we had G=ℤn𝐺subscriptℤ𝑛G=\mathbb{Z}_{n}.

We also have the following corrolary on commutative groups and algebras.

Proposition 3.4.1.

If G𝐺G is a commutative group, then any irreducible complex representation of G𝐺G is one-dimensional. Similarly, if 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a commutative Lie algebra, then any irreducible complex representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is one-dimensional.

Now we are ready to give a classification of irreducible representations of ℝℝ\mathbb{R} and 𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1}

Example 3.4.2.

Let G=ℝ𝐺ℝG=\mathbb{R}. Then the only irreducible representations of G𝐺G are one-dimensional (which follows either from the proposition above, or from Example 3.4.2), and are given by t↦eλ​tmaps-to𝑡superscript𝑒𝜆𝑡t\mapsto e^{\lambda t} for some λ∈ℂ𝜆ℂ\lambda\in\mathbb{C}. Similarly, the only irreducible representations of 𝕊1=ℝ/ℤsuperscript𝕊1ℝℤ\mathbb{S}^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z} are one-dimensional complex spaces Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} for k∈ℤ𝑘ℤk\in\mathbb{Z}, and are given by t↦e2​π​i​k​tmaps-to𝑡superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑡t\mapsto e^{2\pi ikt}.

3.5 Complete irreducibility of unitary representations, representations on finite groups

Definition 3.5.1.

A complex representation V𝑉V of a real group G𝐺G is unitary if there exists a G𝐺G-invariant inner-product (i.e. positive Hermitian form) on V𝑉V: ρ​(G)⊆U​(V)𝜌𝐺𝑈𝑉\rho(G)\subseteq U(V). Similarly, a representation V𝑉V of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is unitary if there exists a 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}-invariant inner-product on V𝑉V: ρ​(𝔤)⊆𝔲​(V)𝜌𝔤𝔲𝑉\rho(\mathfrak{g})\subseteq\mathfrak{u}(V), or equivalently (ρ​(x)​v,w)+(v,ρ​(x)​w)=0𝜌𝑥𝑣𝑤𝑣𝜌𝑥𝑤0(\rho(x)v,w)+(v,\rho(x)w)=0 for all x∈𝔤,v,w∈Vformulae-sequence𝑥𝔤𝑣𝑤𝑉x\in\mathfrak{g},v,w\in V.

Theorem 19.

Unitary representations are completely reducible.

Proof.

We proceed by induction on the dimension of V𝑉V. To perform the inductive step, we use the fact that if W𝑊W is a subrepresentation, then W⟂superscript𝑊perpendicular-toW^{\perp} is a subrepresentation as well. ∎

Example 3.5.1 (Unitary representations).
  1. (i)

    If G𝐺G acts by permutations on a finite set S𝑆S, then the representation ρ​(g)​f​=def​f∘g−1𝜌𝑔𝑓def𝑓superscript𝑔1\rho(g)f\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}f\circ g^{-1} on the space F​(S)𝐹𝑆F(S) of complex functions over S𝑆S is unitary.

  2. (ii)

    Representations of finite groups.

  3. (iii)

    Representations of compact groups (see Theorem 22), e.g. finite groups, SU⁡(n)SU𝑛\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(n), SO⁡(n)SO𝑛\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(n), U​(n)U𝑛\mathrm{U}(n), SO​(n)SO𝑛\mathrm{SO}(n).

3.6 Haar measure on compact Lie groups

Since the proof that finite group representations are unitary is based on the existence of a right-invariant integral on the group, it is natural to ask whether a similar result holds for a broader class of Lie groups.

Definition 3.6.1.

A right Haar measure on a Lie group G𝐺G is a measure μ𝜇\mu on G𝐺G that is invariant under the right action of G𝐺G on itself: Rg∗​μ=μsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑔𝜇𝜇R_{g}^{*}\mu=\mu. Equivalently ∫Gf​(g)​𝑑μ​(g)=∫Gf​(g​h)​𝑑μ​(g)subscript𝐺𝑓𝑔differential-d𝜇𝑔subscript𝐺𝑓𝑔ℎdifferential-d𝜇𝑔\int_{G}f(g)d\mu(g)=\int_{G}f(gh)d\mu(g) for all h∈Gℎ𝐺h\in G and integrable functions f𝑓f on G𝐺G.

Theorem 20.

Let G𝐺G be a real Lie group.

  1. 1.

    Then G𝐺G is orientable and admits an orientation that is invariant under the right action of G𝐺G on itself.

  2. 2.

    If G𝐺G is compact, then for a fixed choice of right-invariant orientation on G𝐺G, there exists a unique right-invariant top degree non-vanishing differential form ω𝜔\omega such that ∫Gω=1subscript𝐺𝜔1\int_{G}\omega=1. This form is left-invariant and left-invariant and invariant up to a sign under i:g↦g−1,i∗​ω=(−1)dimG​ω:𝑖formulae-sequencemaps-to𝑔superscript𝑔1superscript𝑖𝜔superscript1dimension𝐺𝜔i:g\mapsto g^{-1},i^{*}\omega=(-1)^{\dim G}\omega.

Theorem 21.

Let G𝐺G be a compact Lie group. Then G𝐺G admits a right Haar measure, which is a Borel measure, and invariant under the right and left actions of G𝐺G on itself, and under inversion i:g↦g−1:𝑖maps-to𝑔superscript𝑔1i:g\mapsto g^{-1}.

Example 3.6.1.

The Haar measure for G=S1=ℝ/ℤ𝐺superscript𝑆1ℝℤG=S^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z} is the Lebesgue measure d​xd𝑥\,\mathrm{d}x on [0,1]01[0,1].

Theorem 22.

Any finite-dimensional representation of a compact Lie group is unitary and thus completely reducible.

3.7 Orthogonality of characters and Peter–Weyl theorem

Throughout this section, we will assume that G𝐺G is a compact real Lie group with Haar measure d​gd𝑔\,\mathrm{d}g. In the previous section, we saw that it is completely reducible, but we have no way of knowing what the factors of G𝐺G are, or what the multiplicities are. This is what we will try to discuss in this section.

When V𝑉V is a representation of G𝐺G and visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} a basis for V𝑉V, we can consider the matrix corresponding to ρ​(g)∈GL⁡(V)𝜌𝑔GL𝑉\rho(g)\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V) in this basis, and denote with ρi​jsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑗\rho_{ij} its coefficients. In this way we obtain scalar-valued functions ρi​j​(g)subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑔\rho_{ij}(g) on G𝐺G.

We will make use of the following inner product on functions over G𝐺G:

(f,g)=∫Gf​(g)​g​(g)¯​dg.𝑓𝑔subscript𝐺𝑓𝑔¯𝑔𝑔differential-d𝑔(f,g)=\int_{G}f(g)\overline{g(g)}\,\mathrm{d}g. (3.1)

The next theorem tells us that irreducible representations of a compact Lie group G𝐺G can give us an orthogonal set of functions on G𝐺G.

Theorem 23.

Let G𝐺G be a compact real Lie group with Haar measure d​gd𝑔\,\mathrm{d}g.

  1. (i)

    Let V,W𝑉𝑊V,W be non-isomorphic irreducible representations of G𝐺G with basis vi,wasubscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑤𝑎v_{i},w_{a}. Then the corresponding matrix coefficients are orthogonal:

    (ρi​jV,ρa​bW)=0subscriptsuperscript𝜌𝑉𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜌𝑊𝑎𝑏0\left(\rho^{V}_{ij},\rho^{W}_{ab}\right)=0

    for all i,j,a,b𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑏i,j,a,b, where the inner-product is defined as in Equation 3.1.

  2. (ii)

    Let V𝑉V be an irreducible representation of G𝐺G, and visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} be an orthonormal basis with respect to a G𝐺G-invariant inner product. Then the matrix coefficients ρi​j​(g)subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑔\rho_{ij}(g) are orthogonal:

    (ρi​j,ρk​l)=δi​k​δj​ldimV.subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗subscript𝜌𝑘𝑙subscript𝛿𝑖𝑘subscript𝛿𝑗𝑙dimension𝑉\left(\rho_{ij},\rho_{kl}\right)=\frac{\delta_{ik}\delta_{jl}}{\dim V}.

It is evident though that the set of matrix coefficients does depend on the choice of basis for the vector spaces. For this reason, one considers a linear combination of coefficients that is basis-independent.

Definition 3.7.1.

A character of a representation V𝑉V of a real Lie group G𝐺G is the scalar function on the group defined by

χV​(g)=trV⁡ρ​(g)=∑iρi​i​(g),subscript𝜒𝑉𝑔subscripttr𝑉𝜌𝑔subscript𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖𝑖𝑔\chi_{V}(g)=\operatorname{tr}_{V}\rho(g)=\sum_{i}\rho_{ii}(g),

where ρi​j​(g)subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑔\rho_{ij}(g) are the matrix coefficients of ρ​(g)𝜌𝑔\rho(g) in some basis of V𝑉V.

We have the following properties:

Proposition 3.7.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of a real Lie group G𝐺G.

  1. (i)

    If V=ℂ𝑉ℂV=\mathbb{C} is the trivial representation, then χV​(g)=1subscript𝜒𝑉𝑔1\chi_{V}(g)=1.

  2. (ii)

    χV⊕W=χV+χWsubscript𝜒direct-sum𝑉𝑊subscript𝜒𝑉subscript𝜒𝑊\chi_{V\oplus W}=\chi_{V}+\chi_{W}.

  3. (iii)

    χV⊗W=χV​χWsubscript𝜒tensor-product𝑉𝑊subscript𝜒𝑉subscript𝜒𝑊\chi_{V\otimes W}=\chi_{V}\chi_{W}.

  4. (iv)

    Characters are conjugation invariant: χV​(h​g​h−1)=χV​(g)subscript𝜒𝑉ℎ𝑔superscriptℎ1subscript𝜒𝑉𝑔\chi_{V}(hgh^{-1})=\chi_{V}(g).

  5. (v)

    If G𝐺G is compact, then χV∗=χV¯subscript𝜒superscript𝑉¯subscript𝜒𝑉\chi_{V^{*}}=\overline{\chi_{V}}.

The following theorem which follows from the orthogonality of matrix coefficients, tells us that characters of irreducible representations of a compact Lie group form an orthogonal family of functions on G𝐺G.

Theorem 24.

Let G𝐺G be a compact real Lie group with Haar measure d​gd𝑔\,\mathrm{d}g.

  1. (i)

    Characters of non-isomorphic irreducible representations of G𝐺G are orthogonal:

    (χV,χW)=0subscript𝜒𝑉subscript𝜒𝑊0\left(\chi_{V},\chi_{W}\right)=0

    for all non-isomorphic irreducible representations V,W𝑉𝑊V,W.

  2. (ii)

    For any representation V𝑉V of G𝐺G we have

    (χV,χV)=1​ if and only if ​V​ is irreducible.subscript𝜒𝑉subscript𝜒𝑉1 if and only if 𝑉 is irreducible\left(\chi_{V},\chi_{V}\right)=1\text{ if and only if }V\text{ is irreducible}.
  3. (iii)

    The set {χV:V∈G^}conditional-setsubscript𝜒𝑉𝑉^𝐺\left\{\chi_{V}:V\in\hat{G}\right\} is an orthonormal family of functions of G𝐺G, where G^^𝐺\hat{G} is the set of isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of G𝐺G.

  4. (iv)

    For any representation V𝑉V of G𝐺G we can compute its multiplicities via:

    ni=(χV,χVi),subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝜒𝑉subscript𝜒subscript𝑉𝑖n_{i}=\left(\chi_{V},\chi_{V_{i}}\right),

    where V=⊕ini​Vi𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖V=\oplus_{i}n_{i}V_{i}, and Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i} are pair-wise non-isomorphic irreducible representations.

Note that the last part of the theorem implies in particular that the factors and the multiplicities of a completely reducible representation of a compact Lie group can be computed from its character and are unique.

Returning to the matrix coefficients of representations, one might ask whether it is possible to give a formulation of their orthogonality in a way that does not require a choice of basis. The answer is “yes”. Indeed, let v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V, v∗∈V∗superscript𝑣superscript𝑉v^{*}\in V^{*}. Then we can define a function on the group ρv∗,v​(g)subscript𝜌superscript𝑣𝑣𝑔\rho_{v^{*},v}(g) by

ρv∗,v​(g)=⟨v∗,ρ​(g)​v⟩,subscript𝜌superscript𝑣𝑣𝑔superscript𝑣𝜌𝑔𝑣\rho_{v^{*},v}(g)=\langle v^{*},\rho(g)v\rangle,

and this correspondence extends to a mapping V∗⊗V→C∞​(G,ℂ)→tensor-productsuperscript𝑉𝑉superscript𝐶𝐺ℂV^{*}\otimes V\rightarrow C^{\infty}(G,\mathbb{C}) This is a generalization of a matrix coefficient: if v=vj,v∗=vj∗formulae-sequence𝑣subscript𝑣𝑗superscript𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑗v=v_{j},v^{*}=v_{j}^{*}, we recover matrix coefficient ρi​j​(g)subscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑔\rho_{ij}(g).

The space V∗⊗Vtensor-productsuperscript𝑉𝑉V^{*}\otimes V has additional structure. First, we have two commuting actions of G𝐺G on it, given by action on the first factor and on the second one; in other words, V∗⊗Vtensor-productsuperscript𝑉𝑉V^{*}\otimes V is a G𝐺G-bimodule. In addition, if V𝑉V is unitary, then the inner product defines an inner product on V∗superscript𝑉V^{*} (the simplest way to define it is to say that if visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} is an orthonormal basis in V𝑉V, then the dual basis vi∗superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i}^{*} is an orthonormal basis in V∗superscript𝑉V^{*}). Define an inner product on V∗⊗Vtensor-productsuperscript𝑉𝑉V^{*}\otimes V by

⟨v1∗⊗w1,v2∗⊗w2⟩=1dimV​⟨v1∗,v2∗⟩​⟨w1,w2⟩.tensor-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑤1tensor-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑣2subscript𝑤21dimension𝑉superscriptsubscript𝑣1superscriptsubscript𝑣2subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2\langle v_{1}^{*}\otimes w_{1},v_{2}^{*}\otimes w_{2}\rangle=\frac{1}{\dim V}\langle v_{1}^{*},v_{2}^{*}\rangle\langle w_{1},w_{2}\rangle. (3.2)
Theorem 25 (Peter-Weyl theorem).

Let G^^𝐺\hat{G} be the set of isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of G𝐺G. Define the map

m:⨁Vi∈G^Vi∗⊗Vi:𝑚subscriptdirect-sumsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝐺tensor-productsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖\displaystyle m:\bigoplus_{V_{i}\in\hat{G}}V_{i}^{*}\otimes V_{i} →C∞​(G,ℂ), by→absentsuperscript𝐶𝐺ℂ by\displaystyle\rightarrow C^{\infty}(G,\mathbb{C}),\text{ by}
v∗⊗vtensor-productsuperscript𝑣𝑣\displaystyle v^{*}\otimes v ↦⟨v∗,ρ​(⋅)​v⟩.maps-toabsentsuperscript𝑣𝜌⋅𝑣\displaystyle\mapsto\langle v^{*},\rho(\cdot)v\rangle.

Then

  1. (i)

    m𝑚m is an isomorphism of G𝐺G-bimodules, i.e. it is a linear isomorphism that commutes with the actions of G𝐺G on the domain and the codomain:

    m​((g​v∗)⊗v)𝑚tensor-product𝑔superscript𝑣𝑣\displaystyle m((gv^{*})\otimes v) =Lg​(m​(v∗⊗v)),absentsubscript𝐿𝑔𝑚tensor-productsuperscript𝑣𝑣\displaystyle=L_{g}(m(v^{*}\otimes v)),
    m​(v∗⊗(g​v))𝑚tensor-productsuperscript𝑣𝑔𝑣\displaystyle m(v^{*}\otimes(gv)) =Rg​(m​(v∗⊗v)),absentsubscript𝑅𝑔𝑚tensor-productsuperscript𝑣𝑣\displaystyle=R_{g}(m(v^{*}\otimes v)),

    where Rg,Lgsubscript𝑅𝑔subscript𝐿𝑔R_{g},L_{g} are the right and left actions of G𝐺G on C∞​(G,ℂ)superscript𝐶𝐺ℂC^{\infty}(G,\mathbb{C}) given by (Rg​f)​(x)=f​(x​g)subscript𝑅𝑔𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑔(R_{g}f)(x)=f(xg) and (Lg​f)​(x)=f​(g−1​x)subscript𝐿𝑔𝑓𝑥𝑓superscript𝑔1𝑥(L_{g}f)(x)=f(g^{-1}x).

  2. (ii)

    The map m𝑚m extends to a Hilber spaces isomorphism:

    ⨁^Vi∈G^​Vi∗⊗Vi​→≃​L2​(G,d​g),tensor-productsubscript^direct-sumsubscript𝑉𝑖^𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑉𝑖similar-to-or-equals→superscript𝐿2𝐺d𝑔\hat{\bigoplus}_{V_{i}\in\hat{G}}V_{i}^{*}\otimes V_{i}\overset{\simeq}{\rightarrow}L^{2}(G,\,\mathrm{d}g),

    where ⊕^^direct-sum\hat{\oplus} denotes the Hilbert space direct sum i.e. the completion of the algebraic direct sum with respect to the metric given by inner product defined by Equation 3.2, and L2​(G,d​g)superscript𝐿2𝐺d𝑔L^{2}(G,\,\mathrm{d}g) is the Hilbert space of complex-valued square-integrable functions on G with respect to the Haar measure, with the inner product defined by Equation 3.1.

  3. (iii)

    The set of characters

    {χV:V∈G^}conditional-setsubscript𝜒𝑉𝑉^𝐺\left\{\chi_{V}:V\in\hat{G}\right\}

    is an orthonormal basis of the space (L2​(G,d​g))Gsuperscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝐺d𝑔𝐺\left(L^{2}(G,\,\mathrm{d}g)\right)^{G} of conjugation invariant functions on G𝐺G, where G^^𝐺\hat{G} denotes the isomorphism classes of irreducible representations of G𝐺G.

The following example suggests that the study of L2​(G)superscript𝐿2𝐺L^{2}(G) can be considered as a generalisation of harmonic analysis:

Example 3.7.1.

Let G=𝕊1=ℝ/ℤ𝐺superscript𝕊1ℝℤG=\mathbb{S}^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z}. As we have already discussed, the Haar measure on G𝐺G is given by d​x𝑑𝑥dx and the irreducible representations are parametrized by ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}: for any k∈ℤ𝑘ℤk\in\mathbb{Z}, we have one-dimensional representation Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} with the action of 𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1} given by ρ​(a)=e2​π​i​k​a𝜌𝑎superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑎\rho(a)=e^{2\pi ika}. The corresponding matrix coefficient is the same as character and is given by χk​(a)=e2​π​i​k​asubscript𝜒𝑘𝑎superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑎\chi_{k}(a)=e^{2\pi ika}.

Then the orthogonality relation of matrix coefficients gives

∫01e2​π​i​k​x​e2​π​i​l​x​𝑑x=δk​l,superscriptsubscript01superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑥superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑙𝑥differential-d𝑥subscript𝛿𝑘𝑙\int_{0}^{1}e^{2\pi ikx}e^{2\pi ilx}\,dx=\delta_{kl},

which is the usual orthogonality relation for exponents. The Peter–Weyl theorem in this case just says that the exponents e2​π​i​k​x,k∈ℤsuperscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑥𝑘ℤe^{2\pi ikx},k\in\mathbb{Z}, form an orthonormal basis of L2​(𝕊1,d​x)superscript𝐿2superscript𝕊1𝑑𝑥L^{2}(\mathbb{S}^{1},dx) which is one of the main statements of the theory of Fourier series: every L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} function on 𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1} can be written as a series f​(x)=∑k∈ℤck​e2​π​i​k​x𝑓𝑥subscript𝑘ℤsubscript𝑐𝑘superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑘𝑥f(x)=\sum_{k\in\mathbb{Z}}c_{k}e^{2\pi ikx} which converges in L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} metric. For this reason, the study of the structure of L2​(G)superscript𝐿2𝐺L^{2}(G) can be considered as a generalization of harmonic analysis.

3.8 Representation theory of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C})

Throughout this section, when we consider a representation V𝑉V of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}), we will denote the action of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) on V𝑉V by x​v𝑥𝑣xv instead of ρ∗​(x)​vsubscript𝜌𝑥𝑣\rho_{*}(x)v. Note also that the following results are valid for the algebras 𝔰​𝔲​(2)𝔰𝔲2\mathfrak{su}(2) and 𝔰​𝔬​(3)𝔰𝔬3\mathfrak{so}(3), since they are isomorphic to 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}).

Theorem 26.

Any finite-dimensional representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is completely reducible.

Proof.

This is because 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is the complexification of 𝔰​𝔲⁡(2)𝔰𝔲2\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(2), which is compact, and thus unitary. ∎

Recall that 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) has a basis e,f,h𝑒𝑓ℎe,f,h given by

e=(0100),f=(0010),f=(100−1),formulae-sequence𝑒matrix0100formulae-sequence𝑓matrix0010𝑓matrix1001e=\begin{pmatrix}0&1\\ 0&0\end{pmatrix},f=\begin{pmatrix}0&0\\ 1&0\end{pmatrix},f=\begin{pmatrix}1&0\\ 0&-1\end{pmatrix},

that satisfy the commutation relations

[h,e]=2​e,[h,f]=−2​f,[e,f]=h.formulae-sequenceℎ𝑒2𝑒formulae-sequenceℎ𝑓2𝑓𝑒𝑓ℎ[h,e]=2e,[h,f]=-2f,[e,f]=h.
Definition 3.8.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). A vector v∈V𝑣𝑉v\in V is called a vector of weight λ∈ℂ𝜆ℂ\lambda\in\mathbb{C} if it is an eigenvector of hℎh with eigenvalue λ𝜆\lambda:

h​v=λ​v.ℎ𝑣𝜆𝑣hv=\lambda v.

The subspaces of vectors of weight λ𝜆\lambda are denoted by V​[λ]𝑉delimited-[]𝜆V[\lambda]. A "highest weight" of V𝑉V is a weight λ𝜆\lambda (meaning that V​[λ]≠0𝑉delimited-[]𝜆0V[\lambda]\neq 0) with maximal real part, i.e. ℜ⁡λ≥ℜ⁡μ𝜆𝜇\Re\lambda\geq\Re\mu for all weights μ𝜇\mu of V𝑉V.

Lemma 3.8.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). Then for every λ∈ℂ𝜆ℂ\lambda\in\mathbb{C}:

e​V​[λ]⊆V​[λ+2], and ​f​V​[λ]⊆V​[λ−2].formulae-sequence𝑒𝑉delimited-[]𝜆𝑉delimited-[]𝜆2 and 𝑓𝑉delimited-[]𝜆𝑉delimited-[]𝜆2eV[\lambda]\subseteq V[\lambda+2],\text{ and }fV[\lambda]\subseteq V[\lambda-2].

Given the above relations, one can show that every finite-dimensional representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is of the form:

V=⨁λ∈ℂV​[λ],𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝜆ℂ𝑉delimited-[]𝜆V=\bigoplus_{\lambda\in\mathbb{C}}V[\lambda],

called the weight decomposition of V𝑉V. In fact, we will show below that the weights are integers.

Lemma 3.8.2.

Let V𝑉V be a finite-dimensional representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}), and v∈V​[λ]𝑣𝑉delimited-[]𝜆v\in V[\lambda] be a highest weight vector. Then

  1. (i)

    e v = 0

  2. (ii)

    For

    vk=fkk!​v,k≥0,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑣𝑘superscript𝑓𝑘𝑘𝑣𝑘0v^{k}=\frac{f^{k}}{k!}v,k\geq 0,

    we have

    h​vkℎsuperscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle hv^{k} =(λ−2​k)​vk,absent𝜆2𝑘superscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle=(\lambda-2k)v^{k}, (3.3)
    f​vk𝑓superscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle fv^{k} =(k+1)​vk+1,absent𝑘1superscript𝑣𝑘1\displaystyle=(k+1)v^{k+1}, (3.4)
    e​vk𝑒superscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle ev^{k} =(λ−k+1)​vk−1,k>0.formulae-sequenceabsent𝜆𝑘1superscript𝑣𝑘1𝑘0\displaystyle=(\lambda-k+1)v^{k-1},k>0. (3.5)

Although only finitely many of vksuperscript𝑣𝑘v^{k} are nonzero, it is convenient to consider V𝑉V as a quotient of an infinite-dimensional vector space with basis vksuperscript𝑣𝑘v^{k}:

Lemma 3.8.3.

Let λ∈ℂ𝜆ℂ\lambda\in\mathbb{C} and define Mλsubscript𝑀𝜆M_{\lambda} as the infinite-dimensional vector space with basis v0,v1,⋯subscript𝑣0subscript𝑣1⋯v_{0},v_{1},\cdots. Then:

  1. (i)

    The relations in Equation 3.3 make Mλsubscript𝑀𝜆M_{\lambda} into an infinite-dimensional representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}).

  2. (ii)

    If V𝑉V is a finite-dimensional reducible representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}), then V𝑉V is isomorphic to a quotient Mλ/Wsubscript𝑀𝜆𝑊M_{\lambda}/W for some λ∈ℂ𝜆ℂ\lambda\in\mathbb{C} and some subrepresentation W𝑊W of Mλsubscript𝑀𝜆M_{\lambda}.

Theorem 27.

For n≠m𝑛𝑚n\neq m, Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} and Vmsubscript𝑉𝑚V_{m} are non-isomorphic.

Every finite-dimensional irreducible representation V𝑉V of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is isomorphic to Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}, for n=dimV−1𝑛dimension𝑉1n=\dim V-1.

Let V𝑉V be a finite-dimensional representation of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). Then:

  1. (i)

    V admits a weight decomposition with integer weights:

    V=⨁n∈ℤV​[n].𝑉subscriptdirect-sum𝑛ℤ𝑉delimited-[]𝑛V=\bigoplus_{n\in\mathbb{Z}}V[n].
  2. (ii)

    dimV​[n]=dimV​[−n]dimension𝑉delimited-[]𝑛dimension𝑉delimited-[]𝑛\dim V[n]=\dim V[-n], and for n≥0𝑛0n\geq 0, the maps

    en:V​[n]:superscript𝑒𝑛𝑉delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle e^{n}:V[n] →V​[−n],→absent𝑉delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\rightarrow V[-n],
    fn:V​[−n]:superscript𝑓𝑛𝑉delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle f^{n}:V[-n] →V​[n],→absent𝑉delimited-[]𝑛\displaystyle\rightarrow V[n],

    are isomorphisms.

Chapter 4 Structure theory of Lie algebras

In this chapter we will discuss the structure theory of Lie algebras, with the eventual goal of the full classification of semi-siple Lie algebras and their representations. In this chapter 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} will be a finite-dimensional Lie algebra over 𝕂∈{ℝ,ℂ}𝕂ℝℂ\mathbb{K}\in\{\mathbb{R},\mathbb{C}\}.

4.1 Universal enveloping algebra

Note that while there exists no product in a Lie algebra V𝑉V, for every representation ρ:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩​V:𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{gl}{V} the product ρ​(x)​ρ​(y)𝜌𝑥𝜌𝑦\rho(x)\rho(y) is well-defined. While this may indeed depend on the representation ρ𝜌\rho, the commutation relations of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} are preserved by the representation, and thus the product ρ​(x)​ρ​(y)−ρ​(y)​ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥𝜌𝑦𝜌𝑦𝜌𝑥\rho(x)\rho(y)-\rho(y)\rho(x) is a well-defined (in the sense of being independent to the representation ρ𝜌\rho) element of 𝔤​𝔩​V𝔤𝔩𝑉\mathfrak{gl}{V}. Motivated by this, we should think of the universal enveloping algebra as the "universal" associative algebra generated by products of operators of the form ρ​(x),x∈𝔤𝜌𝑥𝑥𝔤\rho(x),x\in\mathfrak{g}, and subject to relations imposed by the Lie algebra structure of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

To be more rigorous, we recall the definition of a tensor algebra generated by a vector space V𝑉V:

Definition 4.1.1.

Let V𝑉V be a vector space over a field 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K}.

  1. (i)

    The tensor algebra T​(V)𝑇𝑉T(V) of V𝑉V as the vector space

    T​(V)=⨁n=0∞V⊗n,𝑇𝑉superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑛0superscript𝑉tensor-productabsent𝑛T(V)=\bigoplus_{n=0}^{\infty}V^{\otimes n},

    endowed with the product

    V⊗n×V⊗msuperscript𝑉tensor-productabsent𝑛superscript𝑉tensor-productabsent𝑚\displaystyle V^{\otimes n}\times V^{\otimes m} →V⊗n+m,→absentsuperscript𝑉tensor-productabsent𝑛𝑚\displaystyle\to V^{\otimes n+m},
    (v1⊗⋯⊗vn,w1⊗⋯⊗wm)tensor-productsubscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑛tensor-productsubscript𝑤1⋯subscript𝑤𝑚\displaystyle(v_{1}\otimes\cdots\otimes v_{n},w_{1}\otimes\cdots\otimes w_{m}) ↦v1⊗⋯⊗vn⊗w1⊗⋯⊗wm,maps-toabsenttensor-productsubscript𝑣1⋯subscript𝑣𝑛subscript𝑤1⋯subscript𝑤𝑚\displaystyle\mapsto v_{1}\otimes\cdots\otimes v_{n}\otimes w_{1}\otimes\cdots\otimes w_{m},

    where V⊗0=𝕂superscript𝑉tensor-productabsent0𝕂V^{\otimes 0}=\mathbb{K} by convention. It is the free algebra on the vector space V𝑉V in the sense that it satisfies the following universal property: Any linear map f:V→A:𝑓→𝑉𝐴f:V\to A from V𝑉V to an associative algebra A𝐴A extends uniquely to an algebra homomorphism T​(V)→A→𝑇𝑉𝐴T(V)\to A.
  2. (ii)

    The symmetric algebra S​(V)𝑆𝑉S(V) is the quotient of T​(V)𝑇𝑉T(V) by the ideal generated by elements of the form v⊗w−w⊗vtensor-product𝑣𝑤tensor-product𝑤𝑣v\otimes w-w\otimes v. Fixing a basis x1,⋯,xnsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\cdots,x_{n} of V𝑉V, we have that it is isomorphic to the polynomial ring 𝕂​[x1,⋯,xn]𝕂subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛\mathbb{K}[x_{1},\cdots,x_{n}].

Note that the map i:𝔤→U​𝔤:𝑖→𝔤𝑈𝔤i:\mathfrak{g}\to U\mathfrak{g} can be shown to be injective.

We can now give a rigorous definiction of the universal enveloping algebra of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

Definition 4.1.2.

The universal enveloping algebra U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} of a Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is the associative algebra with unit over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} with generators i​(x),x∈𝔤𝑖𝑥𝑥𝔤i(x),x\in\mathfrak{g}, subject to relations i​(x+y)=i​(x)+i​(y),i​(c​x)=c​i​(x),c∈𝕂formulae-sequence𝑖𝑥𝑦𝑖𝑥𝑖𝑦formulae-sequence𝑖𝑐𝑥𝑐𝑖𝑥𝑐𝕂i(x+y)=i(x)+i(y),i(cx)=ci(x),c\in\mathbb{K} and i​(x)​i​(y)−i​(y)​i​(x)=i​([x,y])𝑖𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑖𝑦𝑖𝑥𝑖𝑥𝑦i(x)i(y)-i(y)i(x)=i([x,y]).

Alternatively, it is the quotient of the tensor algebra T​(𝔤)𝑇𝔤T(\mathfrak{g}) by the ideal generated by elements of the form x⊗y−y⊗x−[x,y]tensor-product𝑥𝑦tensor-product𝑦𝑥𝑥𝑦x\otimes y-y\otimes x-[x,y]:

U𝔤=T(𝔤)/⟨x⊗y−y⊗x−[x,y]:x,y∈𝔤⟩.U\mathfrak{g}=T(\mathfrak{g})/\langle x\otimes y-y\otimes x-[x,y]:x,y\in\mathfrak{g}\rangle.
Example 4.1.1.

When 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a commutative Lie algebra, the universal enveloping algebra is the symmetric algebra S​(𝔤)𝑆𝔤S(\mathfrak{g}).

Note that in this example, the universal enveloping algebra is infinite-dimensional, which is in fact the case for any non-trivial Lie algebra.

Remark 4.1.1.

Even when 𝔤⊆𝔤​𝔩​(n,𝕂)𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑛𝕂\mathfrak{g}\subseteq\mathfrak{gl}(n,\mathbb{K}) is a matrix algebra, multiplication in U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} is different from multiplication of matrices. For example, let e𝑒e be the standard generator of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). Then e2​2=0superscript𝑒220e^{2}2=0 as a 2×2222\times 2 matrix, but not in U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g}- and for a good reason: there are many representations of 𝔰​l​(2,C)𝔰𝑙2𝐶\mathfrak{s}l(2,C) in which ρ​(e)2≠0𝜌superscript𝑒20\rho(e)^{2}\neq 0.

The universal enveloping algebra has a universal property of its own:

Theorem 28 (Universal property of universal enveloping algebra).

Let A𝐴A be an associative algebra with unit over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and a linear map f:𝔤→A:𝑓→𝔤𝐴f:\mathfrak{g}\to A such that f​([x,y])=f​(x)​f​(y)−f​(y)​f​(x)𝑓𝑥𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦𝑓𝑦𝑓𝑥f([x,y])=f(x)f(y)-f(y)f(x). Then there exists a unique algebra homomorphism f~:U​𝔤→A:~𝑓→𝑈𝔤𝐴\tilde{f}:U\mathfrak{g}\to A such that f~∘i=f~𝑓𝑖𝑓\tilde{f}\circ i=f.

Given a representation V𝑉V, we may let A=𝔤​𝔩​(V)𝐴𝔤𝔩𝑉A=\mathfrak{gl}(V) and f=ρ𝑓𝜌f=\rho:

Noting that every ring homomorphism ϕ:R→𝔤​𝔩​(V):italic-ϕ→𝑅𝔤𝔩𝑉\phi:R\to\mathfrak{gl}(V) induces an R𝑅R-module structure on V𝑉V by r⋅v=ϕ​(r)​v⋅𝑟𝑣italic-ϕ𝑟𝑣r\cdot v=\phi(r)v, we can obtain:

Corollary 4.1.1.

The categories of representations of a (not necessarily finite-dimensional) Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} and of U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} modules are equivalent. More concretely, any representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} has a canonical structure of a U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} module, and conversely, every U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} module has a canonical structure of a representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}.

The following example shows us that we can use the universal enveloping algebra to construct interwining operators between representations of a Lie algebra. The element C𝐶C defined below is known as the Casmir element in 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}).

Example 4.1.2.

Let C=e​f+f​e+12​h2∈U​𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝐶𝑒𝑓𝑓𝑒12superscriptℎ2𝑈𝔰𝔩2ℂC=ef+fe+\frac{1}{2}h^{2}\in U\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). Then C𝐶C is central in U​𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝑈𝔰𝔩2ℂU\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}), i.e. C​a=a​C𝐶𝑎𝑎𝐶Ca=aC for all a∈U​𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝑎𝑈𝔰𝔩2ℂa\in U\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}). This calculation is merely based in using the commutation relations of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) to move a𝑎a from one side of C𝐶C to the other.

In particular, for every representation V𝑉V of 𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}), ρ​(C):V→V:𝜌𝐶→𝑉𝑉\rho(C):V\to V is an interwining operator. In particularm, it acts as a scalar on every irreducible representation V​[n]𝑉delimited-[]𝑛V[n], and if V𝑉V is not irreducible, then it can be decomposed into a direct sum of irreducible representations, and ρ​(C)𝜌𝐶\rho(C) acts as a scalar on each of them.

4.2 Poincaré–Birkhoff–Witt theorem

We will assume throughout this section that 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is a finite-dimensional Lie algebra over a field 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} its universal enveloping algebra. We have already seen that when 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is commutative, U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} is the symmetric algebra S​(𝔤)𝑆𝔤S(\mathfrak{g}) and its infinite dimensional. The Poincaré–Birkhoff–Witt theorem gives us a more precise answer to the question of the dimension of U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g}.

Unlike a polynomial algebra, the universal enveloping algebra is not graded. Indeed, if we were to define a degree by deg⁡(x1​⋯​xk)=kdegreesubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑘𝑘\deg(x_{1}\cdots x_{k})=k, then the commuting relation would imply that the degree of [x,y]𝑥𝑦[x,y] is 1, hence homogenous sums of degree-2 elements would not be closed under addition. Instead, U​g𝑈𝑔Ug is a filtered algebra, where the filtration is given by:

Uk​𝔤=span⁡{x1​⋯​xp:p≤k,xi∈𝔤}.subscript𝑈𝑘𝔤span:subscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑝formulae-sequence𝑝𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖𝔤U_{k}\mathfrak{g}=\operatorname{span}\left\{x_{1}\cdots x_{p}:p\leq k,x_{i}\in\mathfrak{g}\right\}.

Then 𝔘​g𝔘𝑔\mathfrak{U}g becomes a filtered algebra:

U​g=⋃k=0∞Uk​𝔤,Uk​𝔤⋅Ul​𝔤⊆Uk+l​𝔤.formulae-sequence𝑈𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝑈𝑘𝔤⋅subscript𝑈𝑘𝔤subscript𝑈𝑙𝔤subscript𝑈𝑘𝑙𝔤Ug=\bigcup_{k=0}^{\infty}U_{k}\mathfrak{g},\quad U_{k}\mathfrak{g}\cdot U_{l}\mathfrak{g}\subseteq U_{k+l}\mathfrak{g}.
Proposition 4.2.1.
  1. (i)

    If x∈Up​𝔤,y∈Uq​𝔤formulae-sequence𝑥subscript𝑈𝑝𝔤𝑦subscript𝑈𝑞𝔤x\in U_{p}\mathfrak{g},y\in U_{q}\mathfrak{g}, then [x,y]∈Up+q−1​𝔤𝑥𝑦subscript𝑈𝑝𝑞1𝔤[x,y]\in U_{p+q-1}\mathfrak{g}.

  2. (ii)

    The associated graded algebra

    Gr​U​𝔤=⨁k=0∞Uk​𝔤/Uk−1​𝔤Gr𝑈𝔤superscriptsubscriptdirect-sum𝑘0subscript𝑈𝑘𝔤subscript𝑈𝑘1𝔤\mathrm{Gr}U\mathfrak{g}=\bigoplus_{k=0}^{\infty}U_{k}\mathfrak{g}/U_{k-1}\mathfrak{g}

    is commutative.

  3. (iii)

    Let x1,⋯,xnsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\cdots,x_{n} be an ordered basis for 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then the monomials

    x1k1​⋯​xnkn,∑ki≤p,superscriptsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑖𝑝x_{1}^{k_{1}}\cdots x_{n}^{k_{n}},\quad\sum k_{i}\leq p,

    span Up​𝔤subscript𝑈𝑝𝔤U_{p}\mathfrak{g}. In particular, each Up​𝔤subscript𝑈𝑝𝔤U_{p}\mathfrak{g} is finite-dimensional.

Theorem 29 (Poincaré – Birkhoff – Witt theorem ).

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a finite-dimensional Lie algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and denote with U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} its universal enveloping algebra.

  1. (i)

    Let x1,⋯​xnsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\cdots x_{n} be an ordered basis for 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then the monomials

    x1k1​⋯​xnkn,∑ki≤p,superscriptsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑘1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑖𝑝x_{1}^{k_{1}}\cdots x_{n}^{k_{n}},\quad\sum k_{i}\leq p,

    form a basis for Up​𝔤subscript𝑈𝑝𝔤U_{p}\mathfrak{g}.

  2. (ii)

    The graded algebra Gr​U​𝔤Gr𝑈𝔤\mathrm{Gr}U\mathfrak{g} is isomorphic to the symmetric algebra S​(𝔤)𝑆𝔤S(\mathfrak{g}), with the isomoprism given by

    Sp​(𝔤)superscript𝑆𝑝𝔤\displaystyle S^{p}(\mathfrak{g}) →Grp​U​𝔤,→absentsuperscriptGr𝑝𝑈𝔤\displaystyle\to\mathrm{Gr}^{p}U\mathfrak{g},
    a1​⋯​apsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑝\displaystyle a_{1}\cdots a_{p} ↦a1​⋯​apmodUp−1​𝔤.maps-toabsentmodulosubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑝subscript𝑈𝑝1𝔤\displaystyle\mapsto a_{1}\cdots a_{p}\mod U_{p-1}\mathfrak{g}.

    and the inverse isomorphism given by

    Grp​U​𝔤superscriptGr𝑝𝑈𝔤\displaystyle\mathrm{Gr}^{p}U\mathfrak{g} →Sp​(𝔤),→absentsuperscript𝑆𝑝𝔤\displaystyle\to S^{p}(\mathfrak{g}),
    a1​⋯​apsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑝\displaystyle a_{1}\cdots a_{p} ↦a1​⋯​ap,maps-toabsentsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑝\displaystyle\mapsto a_{1}\cdots a_{p},
    a1​⋯​alsubscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑙\displaystyle a_{1}\cdots a_{l} ↦0,l<p.formulae-sequencemaps-toabsent0𝑙𝑝\displaystyle\mapsto 0,l<p.
Corollary 4.2.1.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a finite-dimensional Lie algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} and denote with U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} its universal enveloping algebra.

  1. (i)

    The natural map i:𝔤→U​𝔤:𝑖→𝔤𝑈𝔤i:\mathfrak{g}\to U\mathfrak{g} is injective.

  2. (ii)

    Let 𝔤1,g2subscript𝔤1subscript𝑔2\mathfrak{g}_{1},g_{2} be subalgebras of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. If 𝔤=𝔤1⊕𝔤2𝔤direct-sumsubscript𝔤1subscript𝔤2\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{g}_{1}\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{2} as a vector space, then the multiplication map

    U​𝔤1⊗U​𝔤2​→≃​U​𝔤tensor-product𝑈subscript𝔤1𝑈subscript𝔤2similar-to-or-equals→𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g}_{1}\otimes U\mathfrak{g}_{2}\overset{\simeq}{\to}U\mathfrak{g}

    is a vector space isomorphism.

  3. (iii)

    The unversal enveloping algebra U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} is a domain (it has no zero-divisors).

Proof.

For the last point, follows by contradiction after we assume that f,g∈U​𝔤−{0}𝑓𝑔𝑈𝔤0f,g\in U\mathfrak{g}-\left\{0\right\} with unit leading coefficient and f​g=0𝑓𝑔0fg=0. ∎

Clearly the isomorphism between Gr​U​𝔤Gr𝑈𝔤\mathrm{Gr}U\mathfrak{g} and S​(𝔤)𝑆𝔤S(\mathfrak{g}) can’t be extended to an isomorphism between U​𝔤𝑈𝔤U\mathfrak{g} and S​(𝔤)𝑆𝔤S(\mathfrak{g}), unless of course 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is commutative. However the following result is true for general Lie algebras:

Proposition 4.2.2.

The map S​𝔤→U​𝔤→𝑆𝔤𝑈𝔤S\mathfrak{g}\to U\mathfrak{g} given by

Sp​𝔤subscript𝑆𝑝𝔤\displaystyle S_{p}\mathfrak{g} →Up​𝔤,→absentsubscript𝑈𝑝𝔤\displaystyle\to U_{p}\mathfrak{g},
sym​(x1​⋯​xp)symsubscript𝑥1⋯subscript𝑥𝑝\displaystyle\mathrm{sym}(x_{1}\cdots x_{p}) ↦1p!​∑s∈Spxs​(1)​⋯​xs​(p),maps-toabsent1𝑝subscript𝑠subscript𝑆𝑝subscript𝑥𝑠1⋯subscript𝑥𝑠𝑝\displaystyle\mapsto\frac{1}{p!}\sum_{s\in S_{p}}x_{s(1)}\cdots x_{s(p)},

is a 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}-module isomorphism.

Proof.

It is clearly a 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}-module morphism. It is an isomorphism, since it is a sum of isomorphisms Sp​𝔤→Up​𝔤→subscript𝑆𝑝𝔤subscript𝑈𝑝𝔤S_{p}\mathfrak{g}\to U_{p}\mathfrak{g}. ∎

4.3 Lie’s and Engel’s theorems

The following theorem can be thought of as the reason that solvable Lie algebras are nice enough to study.

Theorem 30 (Lie’s theorem on solvable algebras).

Let ρ:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩⁡(V):𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(V) be a complex representation if a solvable Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then there exists a basis in V𝑉V with respect to which all operators ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥\rho(x) are upper triangular.

This theorem is a generalization of the fact that every operator in a complex vector space is upper-triangular in some basis. The proof is based on the following result:

Proposition 4.3.1.

Let ρ:𝔤→𝔤​𝔩⁡(V):𝜌→𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho:\mathfrak{g}\to\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(V) be a complex representation of a solvable Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then there exists an eigenvector in V𝑉V, common to every operator ρ​(x)𝜌𝑥\rho(x).

We have the following corollaries of Lie’s theorem:

Corollary 4.3.1.
  1. (i)

    Any irreducible complex representation of a solvable Lie algebra is one-dimensional.

  2. (ii)

    If a complex Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable, then there exists a sequence of ideals in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}: 0⊆I1⊆I2⊆⋯⊆In=𝔤0subscript𝐼1subscript𝐼2⋯subscript𝐼𝑛𝔤0\subseteq I_{1}\subseteq I_{2}\subseteq\cdots\subseteq I_{n}=\mathfrak{g} such that each Ik+1/Iksubscript𝐼𝑘1subscript𝐼𝑘I_{k+1}/I_{k} is one-dimensional.

  3. (iii)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable if and only if [𝔤,𝔤]𝔤𝔤[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}] is nilpotent.

One might ask if there is an analog of Lie’s theorem for nilpotent Lie algebras. Since every nilpotent algebra is solvable, the result of Lie’s theorem holds, but one could wonder whether a stronger result is true; for example whether operators can be made strictly upper-triangular. This is however false, as we can consider a commutative Lie algebra which acts diagonally in ℭnsuperscriptℭ𝑛\mathfrak{C}^{n}. However, the following result - which also explains the name of nilpotent algebras - and serves as an analog to Lie’s theorem.

Theorem 31 (Engel’s theorem).
  1. (i)

    Let V𝑉V be a finite-dimensional (real or complex) vector space and 𝔤⊆𝔤​𝔩⁡(V)𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\mathfrak{g}\subseteq\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(V) be a Lie subalgebra consisting of nilpotent operators. Then there exists a basis in V𝑉V with respect to which all operators in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} are strictly upper-triangular.

  2. (ii)

    A Lie algebra is nilpotent if and only if all its adjoint operators are nilpotent. In that case, there exists a basis in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} with respect to which all operators a​dx𝑎subscript𝑑𝑥ad_{x} for x∈𝔤𝑥𝔤x\in\mathfrak{g} are strictly upper-triangular.

4.4 The radical. Semisimple and reductive Lie algebras

So far we have defined the notion of solvable Lie algebras, which in a sense are close to being abelian. Now we will introduce the notion of semisimple Lie algebras, which are as far as possible from being abelian, and show that any Lie algebra is built out of a solvable and a semisimple one.

Definition 4.4.1.

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra.

  1. (i)

    The radical rad⁡𝔤rad𝔤\operatorname{rad}\mathfrak{g} is the maximal solvable ideal of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. In particular, it exists and it is unique.

  2. (ii)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is called semisimple if any of the following equivalent statements holds:

    1. a

      It contains no non-zero solvable ideals

    2. b

      It has trivial radical: rad⁡𝔤=0rad𝔤0\operatorname{rad}\mathfrak{g}=0

    3. c

      The Killing form is non-degenerate.

  3. (iii)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is called simple if any of the following equivalent statements holds:

    1. (a)

      𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is not abelian and contains no ideals other than 00 and 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}

    2. (b)

      The commutator [𝔤,𝔤]𝔤𝔤[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}] is orthogonal to the whole algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} with respect to the Killing form: K​([𝔤,𝔤],𝔤)=0𝐾𝔤𝔤𝔤0K([\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}],\mathfrak{g})=0.

  4. (iv)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is called reductive if rad⁡𝔤=𝔷​(𝔤)rad𝔤𝔷𝔤\operatorname{rad}\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g}).

The reason that we exclude abelian algebras from simple algebras, is because we do not want to include one-dimensional algebras in the class of simple algebras. One of the reasons for this is that the following result would not hold:

Proposition 4.4.1.

Any simple Lie algebra is semisimple.

Example 4.4.1.
  1. (i)

    𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is simple: Indeed, recall that ad⁡hadℎ\operatorname{ad}h is diagonalizable with distinct eigenvalues, so its invariant subspaces are exactly the ones spanned by some of its eigenvectors. If I⊆𝔰​𝔩​(2,ℂ)𝐼𝔰𝔩2ℂI\subseteq\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) is a non-zero ideal, then it must be invariant under ad⁡hadℎ\operatorname{ad}h, and thus it must be spanned by a subset of {e,f,h}𝑒𝑓ℎ\{e,f,h\}. However, ade⁡(𝔰​𝔩⁡(2,ℂ))=adf⁡(𝔰​𝔩⁡(2,ℂ))=adh⁡(𝔰​𝔩⁡(2,ℂ))=𝔰​𝔩⁡(2,ℂ)subscriptad𝑒𝔰𝔩2ℂsubscriptad𝑓𝔰𝔩2ℂsubscriptadℎ𝔰𝔩2ℂ𝔰𝔩2ℂ\operatorname{ad}_{e}(\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}))=\operatorname{ad}_{f}(\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}))=\operatorname{ad}_{h}(\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}))=\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}), so the only ideals are 00 and 𝔰​𝔩⁡(2,ℂ)𝔰𝔩2ℂ\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}).

  2. (ii)

    𝔰𝔩(nℂ),𝔰​𝔲(n),𝔰𝔭(n,ℂ),(n,ℂ)\mathfrak{sl}(n\mathbb{C}),\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(n),\mathfrak{sp}(n,\mathbb{C}),\textso{(}n,\mathbb{C}) are semisimple (see next section).

  3. (iii)

    𝔤​𝔩⁡(n,ℂ),𝔲​(n)𝔤𝔩𝑛ℂ𝔲𝑛\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(n,\mathbb{C}),\mathfrak{u}(n) are reductive.

Proposition 4.4.2.

For any Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} and solvable ideal 𝔟⊆𝔤𝔟𝔤\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\mathfrak{g}, the quotient 𝔤/𝔟𝔤𝔟\mathfrak{g}/\mathfrak{b} is semisimple if and only if 𝔟=rad⁡(𝔤)𝔟rad𝔤\mathfrak{b}=\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g}).

Theorem 32 (Levi decomposition).

Any Lie algebra can be written as a direct sum of a semisimple and a solvable Lie algebra:

𝔤=rad⁡(𝔤)⊕𝔤s​s,𝔤direct-sumrad𝔤subscript𝔤𝑠𝑠\mathfrak{g}=\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g})\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{ss},

where 𝔤s​ssubscript𝔤𝑠𝑠\mathfrak{g}_{ss} is a semisimple algebra (not necessarily an ideal) in 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. On the other hand, if 𝔤=I⊕𝔤s​s𝔤direct-sum𝐼subscript𝔤𝑠𝑠\mathfrak{g}=I\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{s}s can be written as a direct sum of a semisimple subalgebra 𝔤s​ssubscript𝔤𝑠𝑠\mathfrak{g}_{ss} and a solvable ideal I𝐼I, then I=rad⁡(𝔤)𝐼rad𝔤I=\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g}).

Proof.

The second statement follows from Proposition 4.4.2. ∎

Example 4.4.2.

The Levi decomposition for the Poincaré group G=SO⁡(3,ℝ)⋉ℝ3𝐺left-normal-factor-semidirect-productSO3ℝsuperscriptℝ3G=\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(3,\mathbb{R})\ltimes\mathbb{R}^{3} is given by

𝔤=𝔰​𝔬​(3,ℝ)⊕ℝ3.𝔤direct-sum𝔰𝔬3ℝsuperscriptℝ3\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{so}(3,\mathbb{R})\oplus\mathbb{R}^{3}.

Indeed, the commutator is given by [(A1,b1),(A2,b2)]=([A1,A2],A1​b2−A2​b1)subscript𝐴1subscript𝑏1subscript𝐴2subscript𝑏2subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2subscript𝐴1subscript𝑏2subscript𝐴2subscript𝑏1[(A_{1},b_{1}),(A_{2},b_{2})]=([A_{1},A_{2}],A_{1}b_{2}-A_{2}b_{1}), so ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} is an abelian ideal. Also (3,ℝ)\textso{(}3,\mathbb{R}) is semisimple, because (3,ℝ)ℂ=𝔰𝔩(2,ℂ)\textso{(}3,\mathbb{R})_{\mathbb{C}}=\mathfrak{sl}(2,\mathbb{C}) which is simple.

Regarding reductive algebras, the reason to consider them is based on the following result:

Proposition 4.4.3.

Let V𝑉V be an irreducible complex representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then any h∈𝔤ℎ𝔤h\in\mathfrak{g} acts on V𝑉V by a scalar: ρ​(h)=λ​(h)​idV𝜌ℎ𝜆ℎsubscriptid𝑉\rho(h)=\lambda(h)\operatorname{id}_{V}, and any h∈[𝔤,rad⁡(𝔤)]ℎ𝔤rad𝔤h\in[\mathfrak{g},\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g})] acts on V𝑉V by 00.

Since from the point of view of representation theory, having non-zero elements which act by zero in an irreducible representation complicates the theory, we are led to consider algebras that satisfy [𝔤,rad⁡(𝔤)]=0𝔤rad𝔤0[\mathfrak{g},\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g})]=0, or equivalently rad⁡(𝔤)⊆𝔷​(𝔤)rad𝔤𝔷𝔤\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g})\subseteq\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g}). But since 𝔷​(𝔤)⊆rad⁡(𝔤)𝔷𝔤rad𝔤\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g})\subseteq\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g}), this is equivalent to rad⁡(𝔤)=𝔷​(𝔤)rad𝔤𝔷𝔤\operatorname{rad}(\mathfrak{g})=\mathfrak{z}(\mathfrak{g}), which is the definition of a reductive algebra. Of course any semisimple algebra is reductive, but the converse is not true, as the following remark shows:

Remark 4.4.1.

A Lie algebra is reductive, if and only if it is the direct sum of commuting semisimple and abelian algebras:

𝔤=𝔷⊕𝔤s​s,[𝔷,𝔤s​s]=0.formulae-sequence𝔤direct-sum𝔷subscript𝔤𝑠𝑠𝔷subscript𝔤𝑠𝑠0\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{z}\oplus\mathfrak{g}_{ss},\quad[\mathfrak{z},\mathfrak{g}_{ss}]=0.

4.5 Invariant bilinear forms and semisimplicity of classical Lie algebras

Recall that a bilinear form B:𝔤×𝔤→𝕂:𝐵→𝔤𝔤𝕂B:\mathfrak{g}\times\mathfrak{g}\to\mathbb{K} is called invariant if B​(adx⁡y,z)+B​(y,adx⁡z)=0𝐵subscriptad𝑥𝑦𝑧𝐵𝑦subscriptad𝑥𝑧0B(\operatorname{ad}_{x}y,z)+B(y,\operatorname{ad}_{x}z)=0 for all x,y,z∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝑧𝔤x,y,z\in\mathfrak{g}. Using it, we can obtain ideals from other ideals:

Lemma 4.5.1.

Let B𝐵B be an invariant bilinear form on 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} and I⊆𝔤𝐼𝔤I\subseteq\mathfrak{g} an ideal. Then I⟂superscript𝐼perpendicular-toI^{\perp} is also an ideal and in particular ker⁡B=𝔤⟂kernel𝐵superscript𝔤perpendicular-to\ker B=\mathfrak{g}^{\perp} is an ideal.

Proposition 4.5.1.

Let V𝑉V be a representation of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} and define a bilinear form on 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} By

BV​(x,y)=trV⁡(ρ​(x)​ρ​(y)).subscript𝐵𝑉𝑥𝑦subscripttr𝑉𝜌𝑥𝜌𝑦B_{V}(x,y)=\operatorname{tr}_{V}(\rho(x)\rho(y)).

Then BVsubscript𝐵𝑉B_{V} is a symmetric invariant bilinear form on 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. When V=𝔤𝑉𝔤V=\mathfrak{g} is the adjoint representation, then B𝔤=Ksubscript𝐵𝔤𝐾B_{\mathfrak{g}}=K is called the Killing form.

The forms BVsubscript𝐵𝑉B_{V} that arise from the representations are useful because they provide a criterion for reductibility, as the following result shows. Later we will see that the special case of the Killing form provides a characterisation of semisimplicity and solvability as well.

Proposition 4.5.2 (Reductivity critierion).

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra admitting a representation V𝑉V for which BVsubscript𝐵𝑉B_{V} is non-degenerate. Then 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is reductive.

Using this, we can show that the classical Lie algebras are semisimple:

Theorem 33 (Semisimplicity of classical Lie algebras).
  1. (i)

    All classical algebras are reductive.

  2. (ii)

    𝔰​𝔩(2,ℂ),(3,ℝ)\operatorname{{\mathfrak{sl}}}(2,\mathbb{C}),\textso{(}3,\mathbb{R}) are simple.

  3. (iii)

    𝔰l(2,𝕂),(n,𝕂)\mathfrak{s}l(2,\mathbb{K}),\textso{(}n,\mathbb{K}) for n≥3𝑛3n\geq 3 and 𝔰​𝔲⁡(n),𝔰​𝔭​(n,𝕂)𝔰𝔲𝑛𝔰𝔭𝑛𝕂\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(n),\mathfrak{sp}(n,\mathbb{K}) are semisimple.

  4. (iv)

    𝔤​l​(n,𝕂)=𝕂​id⊕𝔰​𝔩​(n,𝕂),𝔲​(n)=i​ℝ​id⊕𝔰​𝔲⁡(n)formulae-sequence𝔤𝑙𝑛𝕂direct-sum𝕂id𝔰𝔩𝑛𝕂𝔲𝑛direct-sum𝑖ℝid𝔰𝔲𝑛\mathfrak{g}l(n,\mathbb{K})=\mathbb{K}\operatorname{id}\oplus\mathfrak{sl}(n,\mathbb{K}),\mathfrak{u}(n)=i\mathbb{R}\operatorname{id}\oplus\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(n) have one-dimensional center.

4.6 Killing form and Cartan’s criterion

Theorem 34 (Cartan’s criterion).

Let 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} be a Lie algebra over 𝕂𝕂\mathbb{K} with Killing form K𝐾K.

  1. (i)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is semisimple if and only if the Killing form K𝐾K is non-degenerate.

  2. (ii)

    𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable if and only if the K​([𝔤,𝔤],𝔤)=0𝐾𝔤𝔤𝔤0K([\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}],\mathfrak{g})=0.

Lemma 4.6.1.

Let V𝑉V be a complex vector space and 𝔤⊆𝔤​𝔩⁡(V)𝔤𝔤𝔩𝑉\mathfrak{g}\subseteq\operatorname{{\mathfrak{gl}}}(V) be a Lie subalgebra. If tr⁡(x​y)=0tr𝑥𝑦0\operatorname{tr}(xy)=0 for all x∈[𝔤,𝔤],y∈𝔤formulae-sequence𝑥𝔤𝔤𝑦𝔤x\in[\mathfrak{g},\mathfrak{g}],y\in\mathfrak{g}, then 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is solvable.

Appendix A Covering theory reminder

In this chapter we recall certain facts and definitions from basic covering theory. A nice reference for these, is the Chapter 2 from [Hat02]. We begin by defining covering spaces.

Definition A.0.1.

A covering map is a continuous surjective map p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X such that for every x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X there exists an open neighborhood U𝑈U of x𝑥x such that p−1​(U)superscript𝑝1𝑈p^{-1}(U) is a disjoint union of open sets in X~~𝑋\tilde{X}, each of which is mapped homeomorphically onto U𝑈U by p𝑝p.

The prototypical example of a covering map is p:𝕊1→𝕊1,p​(z)=zn:𝑝formulae-sequence→superscript𝕊1superscript𝕊1𝑝𝑧superscript𝑧𝑛p:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\mathbb{S}^{1},p(z)=z^{n}.

A.1 Lifting properties

One of the particular characteristics of covering spaces are their lifting properties, that we will recall below.

Proposition A.1.1 (Homotopy lifting property).

Let p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space and a homotopy ft:Y→X:subscript𝑓𝑡→𝑌𝑋f_{t}:Y\to X. Then every lift f~0:Y→X~:subscript~𝑓0→𝑌~𝑋\tilde{f}_{0}:Y\to\tilde{X} of f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} extends to a unique homotopy f~tsubscript~𝑓𝑡\tilde{f}_{t} lifting ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}.

Proof.

See [Hat02, Proposition 1.30]. ∎

This in particular implies the path lifting property of covering spaces:

Corollary A.1.1.

Let p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space. Then for every path γ:I→X:𝛾→𝐼𝑋\gamma:I\to X and every lift x~0subscript~𝑥0\tilde{x}_{0} of some point x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in X admits a unique lift γ~:I→X~:~𝛾→𝐼~𝑋\tilde{\gamma}:I\to\tilde{X} of γ𝛾\gamma starting at x~0subscript~𝑥0\tilde{x}_{0}.

Both of the results above imply that path-homotopies lift to pathhomotopies, where we require for a path homotopy to keep the endpoints of paths fixed. We also have the following corollary that is useful in proving the lifting criterion below.

Corollary A.1.2.

The image subgroup p∗​(π1​(X~,x~0))subscript𝑝subscript𝜋1~𝑋subscript~𝑥0p_{*}(\pi_{1}(\tilde{X},\tilde{x}_{0})) consists of the homotopy classes of loops in X𝑋X based at x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} whose lifts to X~~𝑋\tilde{X} starting at x~0subscript~𝑥0\tilde{x}_{0} are loops.

Proof.

See [Hat02, Corollary 1.31]. ∎

If we care about lifting maps and not homotopies, we have the following criterion that tells us when a lift exists. Namely when f𝑓f sends loops to loops that lift to loops.

Proposition A.1.2 (Lifting criterion).

Let p:(X~,x~0)→(X,x0):𝑝→~𝑋subscript~𝑥0𝑋subscript𝑥0p:(\tilde{X},\tilde{x}_{0})\to(X,x_{0}) be a covering space and f:(Y,y0)→(X,x0):𝑓→𝑌subscript𝑦0𝑋subscript𝑥0f:(Y,y_{0})\to(X,x_{0}) with Y𝑌Y being path-connected and locally path-connected. Then a lift f~:(Y,y0)→(X~,x~0):~𝑓→𝑌subscript𝑦0~𝑋subscript~𝑥0\tilde{f}:(Y,y_{0})\to(\tilde{X},\tilde{x}_{0}) exists if and only if f∗​(π1​(Y,y0))⊂p∗​(π1​(X~,x0))subscript𝑓subscript𝜋1𝑌subscript𝑦0subscript𝑝subscript𝜋1~𝑋subscript𝑥0f_{*}(\pi_{1}(Y,y_{0}))\subset p_{*}(\pi_{1}(\tilde{X},x_{0})).

Proof.

See [Hat02, Proposition 1.33]. ∎

And regarding uniqueness of lifts:

Proposition A.1.3.

Let p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X be a covering space and f:Y→X:𝑓→𝑌𝑋f:Y\to X be a map. If Y𝑌Y is connected, then any two lifts f~1,f~2:Y→X~:subscript~𝑓1subscript~𝑓2→𝑌~𝑋\tilde{f}_{1},\tilde{f}_{2}:Y\to\tilde{X} of f𝑓f that coincide at one point will coincide everywhere on Y𝑌Y.

Proof.

See [Hat02, Proposition 1.34]. ∎

A.2 Universal covering

In this section we will be concerned with proving that under mild conditions, a space has a universal covering, i.e. a simply connected covering space.

Assumption 1.

We consider a topological space X𝑋X that will be path-connected, locally connected and semi-locally simply connected.

While the first two assummptions may seem rather natural, we will now explain the third one.

Definition A.2.1.

A space X𝑋X is semi-locally simply connected if for every x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X there exists an open neighborhood U𝑈U of x𝑥x such that every loop in U𝑈U based at x𝑥x is homotopic in X𝑋X to a constant loop in U𝑈U. In other words, the homomorphism

π1​(U,x)→π1​(X,x)→subscript𝜋1𝑈𝑥subscript𝜋1𝑋𝑥\pi_{1}(U,x)\to\pi_{1}(X,x)

induced by the inclusion is trivial.

To motivate this assumption, we note that it is necessary for the existence of a universal covering. Indeed, if p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X is a universal covering, x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in X and U𝑈U an evenly covered neighborhood of x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}, then any loop in U𝑈U based at x𝑥x lifts to a loop in X~~𝑋\tilde{X} based at some x~0subscript~𝑥0\tilde{x}_{0}. Since X~~𝑋\tilde{X} is simply connected, this loop is homotopic to a constant loop in X~~𝑋\tilde{X} and the homotopy projects down to a homotopy in X𝑋X.

Before constructing the universal cover, we remark that every universal cover X~~𝑋\tilde{X} can be thought of as homotopy classes of paths in X𝑋X starting at some fixed point x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}.

Remark A.2.1.

Let p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X be a universal covering and x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in X. Then the set of homotopy classes of paths in X𝑋X starting at x0subscript𝑥0x_{0} is in bijection with X~~𝑋\tilde{X}. Indeed, given a path γ:I→X:𝛾→𝐼𝑋\gamma:I\to X starting at x0subscript𝑥0x_{0}, we associate it to its endpoint, which defines a map γ~:I→X~:~𝛾→𝐼~𝑋\tilde{\gamma}:I\to\tilde{X}. This map is well-defined since homotopic paths have the same endpoint. It is surjective, beccause X𝑋X is path-connected, while injectivity follows from the fact that X~~𝑋\tilde{X} is simply connected.

We now proceed with the construction of the universal cover by fixing some x0∈Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\in X and letting

X~​=def​{[γ]∣γ​ is a path in ​X​ starting at ​x0},~𝑋defconditional-setdelimited-[]𝛾𝛾 is a path in 𝑋 starting at subscript𝑥0\tilde{X}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\left\{[\gamma]\mid\gamma\text{ is a path in }X\text{ starting at }x_{0}\right\},

and defining the projection map p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X by p​([γ])=γ​(1)𝑝delimited-[]𝛾𝛾1p\left([\gamma]\right)=\gamma(1).

To define a topology on X~~𝑋\tilde{X}, we first consider a convenient basis of open sets for X𝑋X:

𝒰​=def​{U⊆X​ open and path-connected∣π1​(U,x)→π1​(X,x)​ is trivial for some ​x∈U}.𝒰defconditional-set𝑈𝑋 open and path-connected→subscript𝜋1𝑈𝑥subscript𝜋1𝑋𝑥 is trivial for some 𝑥𝑈\mathcal{U}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\left\{U\subseteq X\text{ open and path-connected}\mid\pi_{1}(U,x)\to\pi_{1}(X,x)\text{ is trivial for some }x\in U\right\}.

Note that the above set is well-defined since if there exists some x∈U𝑥𝑈x\in U such that π1​(U,x)→π1​(X,x)→subscript𝜋1𝑈𝑥subscript𝜋1𝑋𝑥\pi_{1}(U,x)\to\pi_{1}(X,x) is trivial, then it is trivial for all x′∈Usuperscript𝑥′𝑈x^{\prime}\in U because U𝑈U is path-connected. To see that it is a basis for X𝑋X, we note that V∈𝒰𝑉𝒰V\in\mathcal{U} for every a path-connected open subset V⊆U𝑉𝑈V\subseteq U.

To each homotopy class [γ]∈X~delimited-[]𝛾~𝑋[\gamma]\in\tilde{X} and U∈𝒰𝑈𝒰U\in\mathcal{U} we associate the set

U[γ]​=def​{[γ⋅η]∈X~∣η​ is a path in ​U​ such that ​η​(0)=γ​(1)}.subscript𝑈delimited-[]𝛾defconditional-setdelimited-[]⋅𝛾𝜂~𝑋𝜂 is a path in 𝑈 such that 𝜂0𝛾1U_{[\gamma]}\overset{\mathrm{def}}{=}\left\{[\gamma\cdot\eta]\in\tilde{X}\mid\eta\text{ is a path in }U\text{ such that }\eta(0)=\gamma(1)\right\}.

Then, given x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X and a neighborhood U𝑈U of x𝑥x, the collection

U[γ]​ for paths ​γ​ going from ​x0​ to ​xsubscript𝑈delimited-[]𝛾 for paths 𝛾 going from subscript𝑥0 to 𝑥U_{[\gamma]}\text{ for paths }\gamma\text{ going from }x_{0}\text{ to }x

U[γ]=U[γ′] for all [γ′]∈U[γ].U[\gamma]=U_{[}\gamma^{\prime}]\text{ for all }[\gamma^{\prime}]\in U_{[\gamma]}.

The proofs that p:U[γ]→Up:U_{[}\gamma]\to U is a homeomorphism for all U∈𝒰𝑈𝒰U\in\mathcal{U} and [γ]∈X~delimited-[]𝛾~𝑋[\gamma]\in\tilde{X} and that X~~𝑋\tilde{X} is simply connected can be found in [Hat02].

An elementary example is the torus:

Example A.2.1.

For X=𝕋2𝑋superscript𝕋2X=\mathbb{T}^{2} being the torus, the universal covering p:ℝ2→𝕋2:𝑝→superscriptℝ2superscript𝕋2p:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{T}^{2} and given by p​(t,s)=e2​π​i​t,2​π​i​s𝑝𝑡𝑠superscript𝑒2𝜋𝑖𝑡2𝜋𝑖𝑠p(t,s)=e^{2\pi it,2\pi is}. Under the identification π1​(𝕋2)≃ℕ2similar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜋1superscript𝕋2superscriptℕ2\pi_{1}(\mathbb{T}^{2})\simeq\mathbb{N}^{2}, which acts on ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} by translations, we have 𝕋2≃ℝ2/ℕ2similar-to-or-equalssuperscript𝕋2superscriptℝ2superscriptℕ2\mathbb{T}^{2}\simeq\mathbb{R}^{2}/\mathbb{N}^{2}.

Having now constructed the universal cover, we now move on to discussing deck transformations.

Definition A.2.2.

A deck transformation of a covering space p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X is a homeomorphism ϕ:X~→X~:italic-ϕ→~𝑋~𝑋\phi:\tilde{X}\to\tilde{X} such that p∘ϕ=p𝑝italic-ϕ𝑝p\circ\phi=p. In other words, the following triangular diagram commutes:

For instance, the fundamental group π1​(X,x0)subscript𝜋1𝑋subscript𝑥0\pi_{1}(X,x_{0}) of X𝑋X acts by deck transformations on the universal cover X~~𝑋\tilde{X}. To each [α]∈π1​(X,x0)delimited-[]𝛼subscript𝜋1𝑋subscript𝑥0[\alpha]\in\pi_{1}(X,x_{0}) we associate the deck transformation ϕ[α]subscriptitalic-ϕdelimited-[]𝛼\phi_{[\alpha]} defined by

ϕ[α]​([η])=[α⋅η].subscriptitalic-ϕdelimited-[]𝛼delimited-[]𝜂delimited-[]⋅𝛼𝜂\phi_{[\alpha]}([\eta])=[\alpha\cdot\eta].

Theorem 35.

The quotient space X~/π1​(X,x0)~𝑋subscript𝜋1𝑋subscript𝑥0\tilde{X}/\pi_{1}(X,x_{0}) is homeomorphic to X𝑋X where the homeomorphism is induced by the projection map p:X~→X:𝑝→~𝑋𝑋p:\tilde{X}\to X as in the following diagram

Appendix B Exercises

In this chapter, we have solutions for certain exercises of [Kir08].

Exercise 1 (Exercise 2.7).

Define a bilinear form on 𝔰​𝔲​(2)𝔰𝔲2\mathfrak{su}(2) by (a,b)=tr⁡(a​b∗)/2𝑎𝑏tr𝑎superscript𝑏2(a,b)=\operatorname{tr}(ab^{*})/2. Show that this form is symmetric, positive definite, and invariant under the adjoint action of SU⁡(2)SU2\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2).

Solution.

It is symmetric since in 𝔰​𝔲⁡(2)𝔰𝔲2\operatorname{{\mathfrak{su}}}(2) we have b∗=−bsuperscript𝑏𝑏b^{*}=-b, so (a,b)=tr⁡(a​b∗)/2=−tr⁡(a​b)/2=−tr⁡(b​a)/2=(b,a)𝑎𝑏tr𝑎superscript𝑏2tr𝑎𝑏2tr𝑏𝑎2𝑏𝑎(a,b)=\operatorname{tr}(ab^{*})/2=-\operatorname{tr}(ab)/2=-\operatorname{tr}(ba)/2=(b,a). It is positive definite since (a,a)=12​∑i,j|ai​j|2𝑎𝑎12subscript𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗2(a,a)=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{i,j}|a_{ij}|^{2}. It is also invariant under the adjoint action of SU⁡(2)SU2\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2) since the trace is invariant under conjugation, and the adjoint representation is given by conjugation. ∎

Exercise 2 (Exercise 2.8).

Consider the usual basis for 𝔰​𝔲​(2)𝔰𝔲2\mathfrak{su}(2):

i​σ1=(0ii0),i​σ2=(0−110),i​σ3=(i00−i).formulae-sequence𝑖subscript𝜎1matrix0𝑖𝑖0formulae-sequence𝑖subscript𝜎2matrix0110𝑖subscript𝜎3matrix𝑖00𝑖i\sigma_{1}=\begin{pmatrix}0&i\\ i&0\end{pmatrix},\quad i\sigma_{2}=\begin{pmatrix}0&-1\\ 1&0\end{pmatrix},\quad i\sigma_{3}=\begin{pmatrix}i&0\\ 0&-i\end{pmatrix}.

Show that the adjoint representation

Ad:SU⁡(2):AdSU2\displaystyle\operatorname{Ad}:\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2) →GL⁡(3,ℝ)→absentGL3ℝ\displaystyle\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(3,\mathbb{R})
g𝑔\displaystyle g ↦ matrix of ​Adg⁡ in the basis ​i​σ1,i​σ2,i​σ3maps-toabsent matrix of subscriptAd𝑔 in the basis 𝑖subscript𝜎1𝑖subscript𝜎2𝑖subscript𝜎3\displaystyle\mapsto\text{ matrix of }\operatorname{Ad}_{g}\text{ in the basis }i\sigma_{1},i\sigma_{2},i\sigma_{3}

gives a morphism of Lie groups SU⁡(2)→SO⁡(3)→SU2SO3\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2)\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(3).

Solution.

Note that the above exercise gave us an isometry between 𝔰​𝔲​(2)𝔰𝔲2\mathfrak{su}(2) and ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}, where the first is equipped with the inner product (a,b)=tr⁡(a​b∗)/2𝑎𝑏tr𝑎superscript𝑏2(a,b)=\operatorname{tr}(ab^{*})/2 and the second with the standard euclidean inner product. Denoting with [Adg]delimited-[]subscriptAd𝑔[\operatorname{Ad}_{g}] the matrix of AdgsubscriptAd𝑔\operatorname{Ad}_{g} in the basis i​σ1,i​σ2,i​σ3𝑖subscript𝜎1𝑖subscript𝜎2𝑖subscript𝜎3i\sigma_{1},i\sigma_{2},i\sigma_{3}, the above isometry tells us AdgsubscriptAd𝑔\operatorname{Ad}_{g} preserves the given inner product if and only if the matrix [Adg]delimited-[]subscriptAd𝑔[\operatorname{Ad}_{g}] preserves the standard euclidean inner product, i.e. [A​dg]∈SO⁡(3,ℝ)delimited-[]𝐴subscript𝑑𝑔SO3ℝ[Ad_{g}]\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(3,\mathbb{R}). Indeed, denoting the isometry with Φ:SU⁡(2)→ℝ2:Φ→SU2superscriptℝ2\Phi:\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2)\to\mathbb{R}^{2}, it gives us an isomorphism

GL⁡(Φ):GL⁡(SU⁡(2)):GLΦGLSU2\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(\Phi):\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2)) →≃​GL⁡(3,ℝ)similar-to-or-equals→GL3ℝ\displaystyle\overset{\simeq}{\to}\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(3,\mathbb{R})
T𝑇\displaystyle T ↦Φ​T​Φ−1maps-toabsentΦ𝑇superscriptΦ1\displaystyle\mapsto\Phi T\Phi^{-1}

and T∈U⁡(2)𝑇U2T\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{U}}}(2) if and only if GL⁡(Φ)∈O​(3)GLΦO3\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(\Phi)\in\mathrm{O}(3). But we saw in the above exercise that the inner product is preserved, so the adjoint representation lies in O​(3)O3\mathrm{O}(3).

To show that it lies actually in SO⁡(3)SO3\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(3), note that the determinant of every matrix in O​(3)O3\mathrm{O}(3) is either 111 or −11-1. However, SU⁡(2)SU2\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2) is connected, so the same is true for ϕ​(SU⁡(2))italic-ϕSU2\phi(\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2)). Since it is connected and contains I3subscript𝐼3I_{3}, so the determinant of the adjoint representation must be 111. ∎

Exercise 3 (Exercise 2.9).

Then P​h​i𝑃ℎ𝑖Phi is given as the composition:

SU⁡(2)→GL⁡(SU⁡(2))→GL⁡(Φ)GL⁡(3,ℝ)g↦Adg↦Φ​Adg⁡Φ−1SU2→GLSU2GLΦ→GL3ℝmissing-subexpression𝑔maps-tosubscriptAd𝑔maps-toΦsubscriptAd𝑔superscriptΦ1missing-subexpression\begin{array}[]{ccccc}\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2)&\to\quad\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2))&\overset{\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(\Phi)}{\to}&\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(3,\mathbb{R})\\ g&\mapsto\quad\operatorname{Ad}_{g}&\mapsto&\Phi\operatorname{Ad}_{g}\Phi^{-1}\end{array}

and thus the matrix of ϕ∗=−2​diag⁡(1,1,1)subscriptitalic-ϕ2diag111\phi_{*}=-2\operatorname{diag}(1,1,1) which is clearly an isomorphism. Exercise 5 (Exercise 3.12).

Let x,y∈𝔤𝑥𝑦𝔤x,y\in\mathfrak{g}. Then ex​ey=ey​exsuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x} if and only if [x,y]=0𝑥𝑦0[x,y]=0. In that case ex​ey=ey​ex=ex+ysuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑥𝑦e^{x}e^{y}=e^{y}e^{x}=e^{x+y}.

Solution.

The if direction follows from the definition of the commutator via Taylor series. For the other direction we follow the method suggested in Exercise 3.11 of [Kir08]:

Ad⁡(ex)​y=ead⁡x​y=∑n≥0(ad⁡x)nn!​y=yAdsuperscript𝑒𝑥𝑦superscript𝑒ad𝑥𝑦subscript𝑛0superscriptad𝑥𝑛𝑛𝑦𝑦\operatorname{Ad}(e^{x})y=e^{\operatorname{ad}x}y=\sum_{n\geq 0}\frac{(\operatorname{ad}x)^{n}}{n!}y=y

But Cg​ez=eAdg⁡zsubscript𝐶𝑔superscript𝑒𝑧superscript𝑒subscriptAd𝑔𝑧C_{g}e^{z}=e^{\operatorname{Ad}_{g}z}, so the above implies that ex​ey​e−x=Cex​ey=eAd⁡(ex)​y=eysuperscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝐶superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑒𝑦superscript𝑒Adsuperscript𝑒𝑥𝑦superscript𝑒𝑦e^{x}e^{y}e^{-x}=C_{e^{x}}e^{y}=e^{\operatorname{Ad}(e^{x})y}=e^{y}. ∎

Exercise 6 (Exercise 3.15).

Let G𝐺G be a connected simply-connected complex Lie group with Lie algebra 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}. Then every real form 𝔨𝔨\mathfrak{k} of 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g} is realised as the Lie algebra of a real form K𝐾K of G𝐺G.

Solution.

Considering 𝔤=𝔨⊕i​𝔨𝔤direct-sum𝔨𝑖𝔨\mathfrak{g}=\mathfrak{k}\oplus i\mathfrak{k}, we define the real Lie algebra automorphism

θ:𝔤→𝔤,x+i​y↦x−i​y.:𝜃formulae-sequence→𝔤𝔤maps-to𝑥𝑖𝑦𝑥𝑖𝑦\theta:\mathfrak{g}\to\mathfrak{g},\quad x+iy\mapsto x-iy.

Since G𝐺G is connected and simply connected, the second fundamental theorem of Lie groups tells us that θ𝜃\theta can be lifted to a Lie group automorphism Θ:G→G:Θ→𝐺𝐺\Theta:G\to G. Then K=GΘ𝐾superscript𝐺ΘK=G^{\Theta} is a real form of G𝐺G with Lie algebra ker⁡θ=𝔨kernel𝜃𝔨\ker\theta=\mathfrak{k}. ∎

B.1 Linear algebra exercises

Exercise 8.

Let A𝐴A be a diagonalizable operator with distinct eigenvalues. Then the invariant subspaces of A𝐴A are exactly the ones that are spanned by some family of its eigenvectors.

First Solution.

Let n𝑛n be the ambient dimension and W𝑊W be an invariant subspace of A𝐴A and consider some complement W⟂superscript𝑊perpendicular-toW^{\perp} of W𝑊W. Considering some basis e1,…,eksubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑘e_{1},\ldots,e_{k} of W𝑊W and ek+1,…,ensubscript𝑒𝑘1…subscript𝑒𝑛e_{k+1},\ldots,e_{n} of W⟂superscript𝑊perpendicular-toW^{\perp}, we have that in this basis A𝐴A is block-diagonal:

A=(A100A2)𝐴matrixsubscript𝐴100subscript𝐴2A=\begin{pmatrix}A_{1}&0\\ 0&A_{2}\end{pmatrix}

where A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} is the restriction of A𝐴A to W𝑊W and A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} is the restriction to W⟂superscript𝑊perpendicular-toW^{\perp}. In particular, the characteristic polynomial of A𝐴A is the product of the characteristic polynomials of A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} and A2subscript𝐴2A_{2}. In particular, A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} and A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} will be diagonalisable with distinct eigenvalues (that are also eigenvalues of A𝐴A). Letting w1,…,wksubscript𝑤1…subscript𝑤𝑘w_{1},\ldots,w_{k} be a basis of eigenvectors of A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}, we see that these must be eigenvectors of A𝐴A as well, so W𝑊W is indeed generated by eigenvectors of A𝐴A. ∎

Second Solution.

Let e1,⋯,edsubscript𝑒1⋯subscript𝑒𝑑e_{1},\cdots,e_{d} be a basis of eigenvectors of A𝐴A. If the result were not true, then there would exist an invariant subspace W𝑊W, some element w=a1​ei1+⋯​ak​eik∈W𝑤subscript𝑎1subscript𝑒subscript𝑖1⋯subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑒subscript𝑖𝑘𝑊w=a_{1}e_{i_{1}}+\cdots a_{k}e_{i_{k}}\in W with a1,⋯​ak≠0subscript𝑎1⋯subscript𝑎𝑘0a_{1},\cdots a_{k}\neq 0 and some j0∈⟦1,k⟧subscript𝑗01𝑘j_{0}\in\llbracket 1,k\rrbracket such that eij0subscript𝑒subscript𝑖subscript𝑗0e_{i_{j_{0}}} is contained in W𝑊W. Without loss of generality assume that j0=ksubscript𝑗0𝑘j_{0}=k. Then

(A=λ1​I)​w𝐴subscript𝜆1𝐼𝑤\displaystyle(A=\lambda_{1}I)w =a2​(λ1−λ2)​ei2+⋯+ak​(λ1−λk)​eik=absentsubscript𝑎2subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑒subscript𝑖2⋯subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆𝑘subscript𝑒subscript𝑖𝑘absent\displaystyle=a_{2}(\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{2})e_{i_{2}}+\cdots+a_{k}(\lambda_{1}-\lambda_{k})e_{i_{k}}=
a2′​ei2+⋯+ak−1′​eik−1superscriptsubscript𝑎2′subscript𝑒subscript𝑖2⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1′subscript𝑒subscript𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle a_{2}^{\prime}e_{i_{2}}+\cdots+a_{k-1}^{\prime}e_{i_{k-1}}

which is contained in W𝑊W and a2′,⋯,ak−1′≠0superscriptsubscript𝑎2′⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1′0a_{2}^{\prime},\cdots,a_{k-1}^{\prime}\neq 0. Keeping on like that, we arrive at ek∈Wsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑊e_{k}\in W, which is a contradiction. ∎

Appendix C Geomtric realisation

Proposition C.0.1.

SU⁡(2)SU2\operatorname{{\mathrm{SU}}}(2) is homeomorphic to 𝕊4superscript𝕊4\mathbb{S}^{4}. In particular, it is simply connected.

Appendix D S​O​(d,d)𝑆𝑂𝑑𝑑SO(d,d)

The goal of this chapter is to show that S​O​(d,d)𝑆𝑂𝑑𝑑SO(d,d) has 2 connected components. First we show that a Lie group G𝐺G has the same number of components as its maximal compact subgroup.

Proposition D.0.1.

Let G𝐺G be a Lie group and K𝐾K its maximal compact subgroup. Then G𝐺G has the same number of connected components as K𝐾K.

Proof.

The Cartan decomposition of G𝐺G tells us that

K×𝔭𝐾𝔭\displaystyle K\times\mathfrak{p} →≃​Gsimilar-to-or-equals→𝐺\displaystyle\overset{\simeq}{\to}G
(k,X)𝑘𝑋\displaystyle(k,X) ↦k​eXmaps-toabsent𝑘superscript𝑒𝑋\displaystyle\mapsto ke^{X}

is a diffeomorphism. Since K×𝔭𝐾𝔭K\times\mathfrak{p} is contractible to K𝐾K, they have the same number of components. ∎

Given this, we just need to calculate a maximal compact subgroup of S​O​(d,d)𝑆𝑂𝑑𝑑SO(d,d).

Proposition D.0.2.

A maximal compact subgroup of S​O​(d,d)𝑆𝑂𝑑𝑑SO(d,d) is S​(O​(d)×O​(d))𝑆𝑂𝑑𝑂𝑑S(O(d)\times O(d)).

Proof.

Clearly it suffices to show that each g∈SO⁡(d,d)𝑔SO𝑑𝑑g\in\operatorname{{\mathrm{SO}}}(d,d) has the form

g=(A00D)𝑔matrix𝐴00𝐷g=\begin{pmatrix}A&0\\ 0&D\end{pmatrix}

for certain square matrices A,D𝐴𝐷A,D, since then they will both necessarily lie in O​(d)O𝑑\mathrm{O}(d). Since the maximal compact subgroup of an algebraic subgroup G𝐺G of GL⁡(d,ℂ)GL𝑑ℂ\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(d,\mathbb{C}) is given by the set of fixed points of the involution A↦(A∗)−1maps-to𝐴superscriptsuperscript𝐴1A\mapsto(A^{*})^{-1}, we see that its Lie algebra 𝔨𝔨\mathfrak{k} is the space of antisymmetric matrices that commute with J=(I00−I)𝐽matrix𝐼00𝐼J=\begin{pmatrix}I&0\\ 0&-I\end{pmatrix}. These are then matrices of the form

x=(A00D)𝑥matrix𝐴00𝐷x=\begin{pmatrix}A&0\\ 0&D\end{pmatrix}

with A,D𝐴𝐷A,D square and antisymmetric. Thus e𝔨superscript𝑒𝔨e^{\mathfrak{k}} has matrices of the desired form and is a generating set for K𝐾K. ∎

Appendix E Case studies

E.1 ℝℝ\mathbb{R}

The representations of 𝔤=ℝ𝔤ℝ\mathfrak{g}=\mathbb{R} are given as ρ∗:ℝ→𝔤​𝔩​(V):subscript𝜌→ℝ𝔤𝔩𝑉\rho_{*}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathfrak{gl}(V), t↦t​Amaps-to𝑡𝑡𝐴t\mapsto tA, where A=ρ∗​(1)𝐴subscript𝜌1A=\rho_{*}(1), and the representations of G=ℝ𝐺ℝG=\mathbb{R} are given by ρ:ℝ→GL⁡(V):𝜌→ℝGL𝑉\rho:\mathbb{R}\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V), t↦et​Amaps-to𝑡superscript𝑒𝑡𝐴t\mapsto e^{tA} for A=ρ∗​(1)𝐴subscript𝜌1A=\rho_{*}(1). E.2 𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1}

The representations ρ:𝕊1→GL⁡(V):𝜌→superscript𝕊1GL𝑉\rho:\mathbb{S}^{1}\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V) are in bijective correspondence with the ones ρ~:ℝ→GL⁡(V):~𝜌→ℝGL𝑉\tilde{\rho}:\mathbb{R}\to\operatorname{{\mathrm{GL}}}(V) such that ρ​(ℤ)=id𝜌ℤid\rho(\mathbb{Z})=\operatorname{id}, since p:ℝ→𝕊1=ℝ/ℤ:𝑝→ℝsuperscript𝕊1ℝℤp:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{S}^{1}=\mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z} is a covering group.

Appendix F Fun facts

Question 6.

What do Lie groups have to do with harmonic analysis?

Answer.

The study of the space L2​(G,d​g)superscript𝐿2𝐺d𝑔L^{2}(G,\,\mathrm{d}g) where G𝐺G is a compact real Lie group and d​gd𝑔\,\mathrm{d}g denotes its Haar measure, can be considered as a generalisation of the classical Fourier analysis on the circle 𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1}, as can be seen by setting G=𝕊1𝐺superscript𝕊1G=\mathbb{S}^{1} (see Example 3.7.1). ∎
